entry.title: SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 1 - Concepts
entry.content:
This three part blog series is designed to help SAP customers define their target sustainability application architecture and roadmap, leveraging the Enterprise Architecture Framework (EAF) methodology.
SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 1 - Concepts
SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 2 - Artifacts
SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 3 - Products and Services

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for my other blogs

 

SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT GOALS

Sustainability requirements are driven by the call to action outlined in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, adopted by the United Nations in 2015 as part of the Paris Agreement. This agenda includes 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that aim to address global challenges such as poverty, inequality, climate change, and environmental degradation. Our main focus is specifically on eight key SDGs, highlighted with a black border, which align closely with our organizational priorities and sustainability objectives.
To effectively support these goals, we prioritize Business Capabilities, which are strategically mapped to the most suitable applications. This approach enables us to define a target application architecture roadmap that supports both sustainable practices and long-term business value. For more information see here

The regulations that are in force for Sustainability are:
CBAM - Cross Border Adjustment Mechanism (2023) (e.g. hydrogen, Cement, Iron, Steel, Fertilizer, Aluminum)
CSRD - Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (2023)
EPR - Extended Producer Responsibility (1990)
ESRS - European Sustainability Reporting Standard (2023)
EUDR - European Union Regulation on Deforestation-free Products (2023) (e.g. soy, beef, palm oil, wood, cocoa, coffee, rubber, and derivate)
ISSB - International Sustainability Standards Board (2024)

 

SUSTAINABILITY AT SAP - TIMELINE

In May 2006 SAP released Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) reporting compliance capabilities for 1st generation EPR policies as a licensed product for SAP R/3 4.6C.
In 2012, with the adoption of Human Rights Commitment Statement, publishing the first integrator report, long before it was legally required or even mainstream. We were the first software company to report on our social and environmental performance alongside our financial performance.
As of 2014 SAP REA (SAP Recycle Administration) was included in ECC core and will reach end of maintenance in 2030 (ECC), and 2040 (S/4HANA). REA services team has transitioned to support SAP RDP and other solutions.
Since 2014, all our data centers and facilities were powered with 100% renewable electricity. While we set our first carbon emission reduction targets in 2009, in 2017, our science-based target CO2 reduction for 2050 was approved.
In 2021 SAP Responsible Design and Production was released as a SaaS solution that provides reporting logic and reports as a service for EPR, plastic tax, and NGO reporting, plus enhanced analytics.
In 2022, we launched SAP Cloud for Sustainable Enterprises. This includes both new products, like the SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and a heritage of longstanding sustainability solutions like SAP Environment, Health, and Safety Management.
In 2023, SAP made the strategic decision to add our leading solutions (SAP Sustainability Control Tower and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management) to the RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, premium plus bundle, exclusively embedding sustainability in our cloud ERP transformation value proposition.
In 2024 SAP Sustainability Data Exchange was added to the SAP Business Network solution area, SAP Green Token was added to the supply chain management solution area and SAP Green Ledger which brings carbon management functionality to the office of the CFO.

 

CARBON EMMISSION SCOPES

Carbon Emissions Scope 1: Direct Emissions from sources that are owned or controlled by the organization (Company owned vehicles, emissions from Stationary Combustion, Mobile Combustion, Fugitive Emissions, and Process Emissions from manufacturing)
Carbon Emissions Scope 2: Indirect Emissions outside of a company’s direct control but are a result of energy consumption from purchased electricity, steam, heat and cooling.
Carbon Emissions Scope 3: Indirect Emissions that are not directly owned and controlled by the organization  including emissions from the supply chain, business travel, employee commuting, waste disposal, and product life cycles. These emissions involve many stakeholders, so collecting accurate data makes measuring and assessing these emissions difficult, and  there is no clarity on who exactly is accountable for reducing.

 

BUSINESS CAPABILITIES:

Sustainability is a key driver of business success and strategic differentiation in the modern economy. To meet changing market demand faster and cheaper and increase resilience for future challenges, sustainability needs to be at the core of every business process.
Sustainability is thus a broad topic that covers a variety of themes and use cases. To address this, SAP offers a modular portfolio that cover most relevant sustainability use cases & capabilities, and can be summarized across four themes:

  • ESG Reporting & Management
  • Carbon Management
  • Material Transition
  • Operational Compliance

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 2 - Artifacts
entry.content:
This three part blog series is designed to help SAP customers define their target sustainability application architecture and roadmap, leveraging the Enterprise Architecture Framework (EAF) methodology.
SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 1 - Concepts
SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 2 - Artifacts
SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 3 - Products and Services

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for my other blogs

This blog outlines our approach to embedding sustainability strategy into the Enterprise Architecture to effectively achieve key sustainability goals. Many organizations may already utilize traditional sustainability applications within the Environmental Health & Safety (EH&S) domain—such as Product Compliance or EHS Incident Management—typically running on legacy platforms like SAP ECC. With the evolving sustainability landscape, organizations are increasingly exploring next-generation SAP sustainability solutions, including SAP Sustainability Control Tower, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Responsible Design and Production.
To support this transition, the Enterprise Architect plays a pivotal role in developing a Target Architecture Roadmap aligned with sustainability priorities. This roadmap is structured around our five-phase Enterprise Architecture methodology, as illustrated below (Phases 1–5). At every phase, sustainability-specific content is integrated to ensure that strategic goals are fully embedded and actionable within the architecture planning and execution processes.

 

Business Model Canvas

The Sustainable Business Model Canvas is a one-page strategic tool that illustrates how an organization creates, delivers, and captures value—with sustainability at its core.
It provides a shared perspective and common understanding of an organization’s business model, enabling informed discussions among business leaders on key issues and the changes needed to support sustainable growth. The canvas encourages a design-oriented approach, helping identify how the business can evolve to maximize value exchanges among market participants in a sustainable manner.
This framework also promotes collaboration and co-creation, supporting the development of both current-state and future-state business models. It emphasizes the key revenue and cost components that underpin an agreed-upon value proposition tailored to specific customer segments.
Below is the Sustainable Business Model Canvas template, which you can use to document your sustainability-focused perspective. Please zoom into the document as needed for better readability.

Source for the template is https://www.strategyzer.com/

 

Business Strategy Map:

Our approach begins with a deep understanding of the customer’s stated strategy and sustainability objectives. Using this input, we leverage our reference content to develop a Strategy Map that aligns strategic intent with actionable business capabilities.
The example in the accompanying graphic illustrates how we map strategic priorities and drivers—such as “Operational Compliance”—to desired goals or outcomes, like “Demonstrate responsibility as a caring company to attract top talent.” These outcomes are then linked to customer-specific objectives or SAP Value Drivers, for example: “Create a workplace free from fatalities and injuries.”
Each value driver is associated with specific business capabilities, such as EHS Incident Management, forming a clear line of sight from high-level strategy down to operational execution. These linkages may come from our reference models or be tailored based on customer engagement and context.
Ultimately, this strategy map provides a crucial input for architecture planning. By identifying the core business capabilities that support the customer’s sustainability goals, we lay the foundation for defining the target application architecture that will enable long-term success.

Strategic Decision Paths:

Strategic Decision Paths for Managing Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) and Plastic Taxes

  • R&D Engineering => Product Compliance Management
  • Finance => Accounting and Financial Close => Sustainability Accounting

The 8 applications mapped to these business capabilities are shown in graphic above, highlighted in the green box are further described in detail in the Product Portfolio section.

Sustainability Capability Heatmap

Business Capability Heatmapping involves assessing and categorizing business capabilities using the SAP Enterprise Architecture Framework, which includes the SAP Reference Business Architecture and SAP Reference Solution Architecture. These capabilities are then mapped to the customer’s business objectives, ensuring a strategic alignment between operational functions and organizational goals.
This heatmapping process serves as a valuable decision-making foundation, helping to identify priority areas for future investment and transformation. It enables stakeholders to clearly see where enhancements, innovations, or optimizations will have the most strategic impact.
The first step in this process is to identify the Business Capabilities in scope.

 

Business Capability Prioritization

The graph below illustrates the prioritization of business capabilities based on their current fulfillment and strategic criticality.
As shown, traditional capabilities such as Dangerous Goods Management and Hazardous Substance Management are positioned on the right-hand side of the graph. These capabilities show a high level of fulfillment, as the customer has been leveraging them for many years—particularly for compliance reporting during goods shipment.
In contrast, emerging sustainability-focused capabilities, including Circular Economy, Sustainability Footprint Management, and EHS Incident Management, are marked by high business criticality but low current fulfillment. These represent strategic opportunities where targeted investment and capability development can significantly advance the customer’s sustainability objectives.
This prioritization helps guide target architecture planning and roadmap definition, ensuring focus on the areas with the highest potential for impact.

 

Applications Architecture Roadmap

The diagram below represents a sample Sustainability Target Architecture Roadmap, developed following a series of workshop sessions organized by business domain. These sessions involved collaboratively sketching the target application architecture and identifying solutions that align with key sustainability business areas.
This roadmap outlines a multi-year, strategic plan focused on enabling and scaling sustainability initiatives across the enterprise. It serves as a practical example that you can leverage as a reference when shaping your own sustainability architecture journey.


 

Target Applications Architecture Diagram

Please find below the Target Application Architecture diagram.

 

Enterprise Architecture Framework Services

Architecture Framework Services leverage a modular service model centered around the North Star Architecture approach, utilizing Enterprise Architecture (EA) tooling and Reference Architecture content. This approach provides flexibility in how services are sourced—they can be delivered by SAP, external providers, or the organization itself performing the EA practice.
These services also support the enablement of various EA target roles within both customer and partner organizations. Delivery can be executed jointly by SAP and customer teams or handled independently by either party, depending on the engagement model.
At the core of this approach are the North Star Architecture service patterns—predefined flows of selected modules designed with varying levels of depth. These patterns offer a structured yet adaptable method to address specific customer challenges and guide the development of a clear, actionable EA roadmap.


Generally for transformation into sustainable enterprise, the key architecture modules in the North Star Service are as follows. You may add more modules as required depending on the customer requirements.

  • Strategy Mapping – This module assesses the sustainability strategic objectives of the organization and how they relate to the goals and value drivers of the organization.
  • Business Capability – This module focuses on heatmapping the business capabilities that are in scope and out of scope and also focuses on pain points with existing applications and opportunities to move to new SAP applications.
  • Application Architecture – This module focuses on designing the target application architecture for SAP sustainability applications, along with the high-level solution components map to provide visibility into the business capabilities mapping to solution capabilities of SAP applications.
  • Initiatives and Roadmap – This module helps to determine a set of transformation initiatives for sustainability; lists the major roadmap clusters, phases, and dependencies; and then sequences them on a relative timescale to create the sustainability roadmap.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 3 - Products and Services
entry.content:
This three part blog series is designed to help SAP customers define their target sustainability application architecture and roadmap, leveraging the Enterprise Architecture Framework (EAF) methodology:
SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 1 - Concepts
SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 2 - Artifacts
SAP Sustainability Architecture - Part 3 - Products and Services

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for my other blogs

SAP Sustainability’s approach is ERP-centric, with modular, integrated, connected and AI-enabled solutions that leverage and extend existing enterprise capabilities.


Here’s a diagram illustrating the layered, modular structure of the SAP Sustainability portfolio, built on a harmonized data model with a common foundation such as S/4HANA and the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
Below is an overview of the SAP Sustainability portfolio (L1 public cloud, as of February 2025; for the latest, please always refer to the Sustainability GTM Workzone). Please find details on each of the products as shown in the diagram:

 

1) SAP Sustainability Data Exchange

The SAP Sustainability Data Exchange integrates seamlessly with our Business Network, ensuring supply chain transparency, compliance, and collaboration at scale.
SAP Sustainability Data Exchange engages with companies’ suppliers and requests and receives accurate footprint calculation from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. SAP Sustainability Data Exchange is a new solution and uses the carbon data interoperability standards established by the Partnership for Carbon Transparency (PACT), hosted by the World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD).
For the latest information and assets, see here.
INTEGRATION: As shown below SDX is a cloud-based solution that facilitates easy sharing of scope 3 emission data between business partners in a standardized way using SAP Business Network, and industry networks, such as Catena-X, Factory-X as data collaboration channels. It transfers Supplier data to SFM, and shares the SFM data with Customer.

 

2) SAP Sustainability Control Tower

SAP Sustainability Control Tower helps to maintain the agility to report with trusted, audit-ready metrics, monitor and steer Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) targets as well as report on sustainability performance beyond carbon (for example covering diversity & equality KPIs). Through the integration with SAP Sustainability Control Tower, corporate footprints that are calculated with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management can now also be integrated into the overall sustainability reporting and used for company-wide holistic ESG reporting and steering.
For the latest information and assets, see here and for strategic decision path see here.
INTEGRATION: From SCT the data is transferred using Outbound API Interface, generally an OData interface for data replication with OAuth 2.0 client credentials. The Inbound Interface is used for Local CSV file upload to commodity pricing engine (CPE) component, Central replication service using SAP BTP destinations and authentication features, SAP S/4HANA integration via SAP BTP destinations and cloud connector for on-premises solutions and SAP Datasphere integration through the ODATA interface. Also uses Inbound API as ODATA interface.

 

3) SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

SAP Sustainability Footprint Management helps companies to calculate their corporate and product carbon footprints across GHG Scope 1, 2, and 3 and embed the results into existing business processes to drive decarbonization. It assesses corporate carbon footprint (CCF) across all GHG-Protocol categories and product carbon footprints (PCF) that consider materials, transportation, and production.
For the latest information and assets, see here and for strategic decision path see here..
INTEGRATION: The data is extracted from SAP S/4HANA End-to-End process, SAP EHS Management, Environment management, SAP Sustainability Data Exchange and Third-party providers and imported into SAP Green Ledger, SAP Sustainability Control Tower Partner's SAP Sustainability Data Exchange or SAP S/4HANA system.

 

4) SAP Green Ledger

SAP Green Ledger allocates carbon emissions to specific economic activities and transactions captured by ERP solutions from SAP. This innovation empowers organizations to accurately account for, analyze and report carbon footprints across products, services, and organizational units.
The figure below shows carbon accounting foundation based on trusted financial processes/structures. Here we treat Carbon like Money like double entry book-keeping.
For the latest information and assets, see here.

 

5) SAP Green Token

SAP Green Token is a software-as-a-service (SaaS) cloud solution that provides traceability and transparency for raw materials in the context of ESG (Environment, Social, and Governance) attributes across the supply chain. Leveraging the innovative principles of Tokenization, Blockchain, and Chain of Custody Models; with segregation or mass balancing and tokenization for trust and compliance with recognized standards. The solution enables accurate raw material accounting, proving material provenance, and transitioning to sustainable material usage.
SAP Green Token captures sustainability attributes and documentation at inbound. Conversions are captured and this data and proof is maintained throughout complex supply chain processes and productions. As a result, full visibility on your raw materials and proof of sustainability is created.
For the latest information and assets, see here.

 

6) SAP Responsible Design and Production

SAP Responsible Design and Production helps design products sustainably and build a regenerative business in a circular economy, e.g. by providing the ability to calculate and report Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) fees and plastic taxes and by giving decision makers a lifecycle view into costs and planetary impact of design choices. It helps producers manage their Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) obligations and plastic taxes so they can control and eliminate the costs of the downstream waste system and make design changes to eliminate waste.
For the latest information and assets, see here.
INTEGRATION: Most data for EPR is coming from Material Management, Sales & Distribution, and Production Planning, as well as packaging information out of SAP PLM or 3rd-party systems. There is option for Data Mapping: Data collection & data mapping using ABAP code. In the middle part, there is SAP Integration Suita and Connectivity Service option for data mapping ERP and packaging data to the RDP unified data model on the right.

 

7) SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Environment, Health, and Safety Management

SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Environmental, Health, and Safety Management (EHS) supports your organization in managing business processes related to the safety of the environment and the health and safety of people. It covers several use cases. In a sustainability context, the most relevant modules are:

  1. SAP S/4HANA Cloud for EHS Environmental Management (EHS EM) ensures companies stay compliant with emissions and permit related environmental regulations. EHS EM encompasses all aspects of environmental compliance along with management of an organization's impact on the environment, including air and water pollution, GHG emission inventory, and waste management.
    For the latest information and assets, see here.
  2. SAP S/4HANA Cloud for EHS workplace safety tracks safety compliance and incidents in the cloud. With advanced and automated safety software that supports hazard identification and risk mitigation, customers can promote a more proactive safety culture to keep workers safe and productive.
    For the latest information and assets, see here.

 

8] SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Product Compliance

Operational Sustainability with SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Product Compliance (PC) supports product safety and compliance throughout the product lifecycle and integrates in all business processes. Use the solution to protect revenue and brand, reduce risk and compliance cost, and streamline compliance processes.
CLASSIC v/s NEW: Classic capabilities of PC are available in S/4HANA on-premise and private cloud and will not be enhanced (migrate by 2031). New PC capabilities are available in SAP S/4HANA on-premise, public and private cloud - new CDS-based business process model, SAP Fiori GUI technology to develop more powerful analytics, enhanced business process integration into product master, sales delivery, procurement and transportation, see here.
For the latest information and assets, see here.

Efficient Execution through SAP Business Suite

SAP is committed to efficient execution of sustainability through SAP Business Suite using One Sustainability Data Model via Business Data Cloud.

 

 

AI for Sustainability

SAP Sustainability portfolio & AI

The SAP Sustainability portfolio leverages artificial intelligence (AI) to drive significant advancements in sustainability across various business functions. The integration of AI into SAP Sustainability solutions enables organizations to enhance their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance through data-driven insights, automation, and predictive analytics.

AI addresses several key challenges in sustainability, including the fragmentation and siloing of sustainability-related data, the complexity and manual nature of sustainability processes, and the difficulty in obtaining accurate and actionable insights. By unifying and enriching data from various sources, AI ensures that organizations have access to accurate and actionable information. It also automates complex tasks, reducing human error and freeing up resources for strategic activities. Additionally, AI provides tailored and predictive insights, enabling informed decisions that optimize both environmental and business outcomes.
Today, AI is already being utilized in various innovative ways within SAP's sustainability portfolio to address key challenges and drive efficiency. Here are some of the most prominent AI use cases:

  1. Emission Factor Mapping in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: AI assists in mapping emission factors to purchased products, significantly reducing manual effort and time and increasing accuracy in calculating product and corporate carbon footprints by up to 80%.
  2. ESG Report Generation in SAP Sustainability Control Tower: AI generates comprehensive ESG reports by automatically collecting relevant metrics, creating visual graphs, and drafting reports based on best-practice templates. This can lead to up to 98% reduction in time needed to collect ESG metrics and 80% reduction in time needed to create and draft reports, allowing sustainability teams to focus on execution and management.
  3. Declaration Image Analysis in SAP Green Token: AI autonomously reviews and extracts information from supplier sustainability declarations, regardless of their format, and posts the data to SAP Green Token.

Further AI use cases are currently in beta or being planned for later in 2025. Below you can find an overview as of May 2025:

For the latest information and assets, see here.

Ethical and sustainable AI

SAP is committed to responsible AI development, ensuring that AI solutions are built with security, privacy, compliance, ethics, and accuracy in mind. Some of the key ethical considerations are:

  • Bias and Fairness: AI must be designed to prevent the encoding of patterns of marginalization, inequality and discrimination.
  • Transparency and Explainability: SAP implements mechanisms to provide clear explanations for the reasoning behind AI-generated outputs, making the model's behavior understandable to users and stakeholders.
  • Privacy and Data Security: SAP ensures that AI solutions comply with data privacy regulations and protect sensitive information from unauthorized access.
  • Human Agency and Oversight: SAP maintains human control over critical decisions and interventions to avoid unintended consequences and ensure ethical use of AI.
  • Continuous Monitoring: SAP continuously monitors AI performance and outputs to detect any deviations from ethical and responsible behavior.

SAP's AI ethics policy, governance model, and sustainable development guidelines ensure that AI use cases have a positive impact on people and the planet.
For the latest information and assets, see here.

 

SAP Sustainability with RISE / GROW

In the second quarter of 2023, SAP launched the Case for Cloud initiative. “Case for Cloud” encompasses all programs and innovation designed to make SAP’s cloud solutions more attractive to our on-premise installed base customers.
IMPORTANT: Strategic Cloud innovations are only being offered in the context of RISE or GROW with SAP.
Two of the Sustainability solutions, namely SAP Sustainability Control Tower and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, as well as the Finance solution SAP Green Ledger, are considered strategic cloud innovations and can thus only be sold to customers with an existing RISE or GROW contract (often referred to as ‘RISE-/GROW pre-rec).
The other Sustainability solutions do not yet have a RISE-/GROW pre-rec, which may change in the future. To stay informed, please refer to the Case for Cloud FAQ.

As of May 2025, there are two existing suite bundles that include Sustainability solutions:

  1. RISE with SAP, Sustainability essentials package with SAP Sustainability Control Tower, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.
  2. SAP Supply Chain Premium (‘SCM Premium’) with SAP S/4HANA Cloud for EHS environment management, SAP S/4HANA Cloud for EHS workplace safety, SAP S/4HANA Cloud for product compliance, SAP Responsible Design and Production, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.

As bundles may evolve, please refer to the latest information regarding commercials to the Sustainability GTM Workzone.

 

SAP Sustainability Service Portfolio

The Sustainability Service Portfolio offers a range of services to meet our customers where they are at – from kicking of the journey, bridging the gap between strategy and execution, to delivering, running and scaling the sustainable enterprise.  
The portfolio includes advisory, assessment, activation and implementation services:

Sustainability Advisory

The Sustainability Advisory helps customers understand the business opportunities and risks related to sustainability and climate action, and helps companies respond by evaluating impacts and outcomes. This scope option provides our customers a holistic approach to kick-off their transformation towards the Sustainable Enterprise.

Sustainability Enablement

Bridge the gap between strategy (sustainability goals and ambitions) and execution (deriving an implementation plan). Identify data in existing systems and link it to an SAP Sustainability solution in order to achieve setting sustainability ambitions.

Sustainability Adoption

Maximize usage and adoption of SAP Sustainability solutions. Different service offerings available, depending on the customer situation. Supporting the explore phase, building a strong foundation in the test tenant, or supporting our customers until business go-live.

There are also as well as options under SAP Premium Engagement and SAP Preferred Success. The holistic portfolio overview and link to sales channels can be accessed here.
NOTE: Sustainability will also be part of the SAP Services evolution program and initiative (expected launch in 2026).

entry.title: Troubleshooting Guide for Known Issues in SAP Green Ledger Analytical Dashboard
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog, I’ll walk you through six common issues encountered in SAP Green Ledger Analytical Dashboard along with step-by-step solutions.

 

Applicable Versions

This troubleshooting guide applies to specific versions only. The issues described in this article are known and will be resolved in the upcoming version. Please stay tuned for the next release.

SAP Analytics Cloud Versions: 1.0.0 and 1.1.0

SAP Datasphere Versions: 1.0.0 and 1.1.1

 

Issue 1 Story Management Error

Symptom

There are alerts marked with exclamation mark icons in the drop-down menu of Add New Data from the toolbar in SAP Analytics Cloud.

Procedure

  1. Open SAP Green Ledger Analytical Dashboard in SAP Analytics Cloud.
  2. Open edit mode.
  3. From the toolbar, select Add New Data > [The Model to be Replaced] > Replace....
  4. If a warning pops up, choose Continue.
  5. In the Select Model dialog, select Select other model... > SAPDWC in the Datasphere section > [Your Workspace Name] > [Model Name] (should match the name of the model to be replaced).
  6. Choose OK.
  7. In the Replace Model panel, choose Preview > Replace Model. For more information, see Replace Models in Stories (Optimized) | SAP Help Portal.
  8. From the toolbar, select Add New Data > [The Model to be Replaced] > Remove to remove the replaced model.
  9. Repeat steps 3 to 8 until all analytic models are replaced.

 

Issue 2 Incorrect CO2e-Flow Statement

Applicable Version

SAP Datasphere Applicable Version: 1.0.0

This issue doesn't occur in the latest version. We recommend upgrading your system to the latest version to resolve the problem.

Symptom

The opening and closing data of CO2e flow statement in SAP Green Ledger Analytical Dashboard isn't correct.

For more information about SAP Green Ledger Analytical Dashboard, see SAP Green Ledger Overview | SAP Help Portal.

Procedure

  1. Download the ZIP file here.
  2. Extract the ZIP file.
  3. In SAP Datasphere, open the Repository Explorer.
  4. Above the result table, choose Import > Import Objects from CSN/JSON File.
  5. Select a space that you want to import.
  6. Select and import the JSON file you just downloaded.
  7. Select all objects with status Ready to Import. Exclude objects marked as Already in the Repository.
  8. Choose Import CSN File.
  9. Once finished, select the imported objects and choose Deploy.
  10. In the Repository Explorer,  search for the business name "Co2e Flow Statement Union (HL)" and open it.
  11. In line 28, replace "OpenTranToCustomers" with "FiscalYearPeriod".
  12. In lines 33 and 66, replace "SAP_GRL_HL_EmissionSumTranToCustomers" with "SAP_GRL_HL_EmissionSumTranToCustomersWOP".
  13. In line 61, replace "CloseTranToCustomers" with "FiscalYearPeriod".
  14. Choose Save and Deploy.

 

Issue 3 Currency or Unit Conversion Error

Symptom

A currency/unit conversion error message occurs while previewing the green ledger analytic model in SAP Datasphere.

Procedure

In SAP Datasphere, search for the technical name "SAP_GRL_HL_JrnlEntrEmissionLdngLdgrUntCnvrsn" in the Repository Explorer.

  • If no results are found, perform the following steps.
    1. Download the ZIP file here.
    2. Extract the ZIP file.
    3. Choose Import > Import Objects from CSN/JSON File.
    4. Select and import the JSON file you just downloaded to space "SAP_CONTENT".
    5. Select all objects with status Ready to Import. Exclude objects marked as Already in the Repository.
    6. Choose Import CSN File.
    7. Once finished, select the imported objects and choose Deploy.
  • If results are found, perform the following steps.
    1. Open the view "SAP_GRL_HL_JrnlEntrEmissionLdngLdgrUntCnvrsn".
    2. Choose Details in the top right corner > fx icon in the data flow > Emission Amount in Columns.
    3. Under the Expression field, locate the line "SCHEMA" => 'SAP_CONTENT'.
    4. Replace the "SAP_CONTENT" to your space name.
    5. Choose Save and Deploy.

 

Issue 4 Duplicate Data Caused by Unsupported Locale Name

Symptom

Duplicate data can occur when an unsupported language locale name is used in SAP Analytics Cloud.

The supported locale for English in SAP Analytics Cloud is "en". However, the data imported from SAP Green Ledger uses the locale "en_US_sapigi", which results in duplicate data.

Note: If you're using a non-English system, this issue won't affect your data output. However, it’s still recommended to perform the following steps to prevent future issues.

Procedure

  1. In SAP Datasphere, search "SAP_GRL_IL_T_GHGEnergyMix" in the Repository Explorer and open it.
  2. Choose Details in the upper right corner.
  3. In the Model Properties screen, choose Edit Columns next to Attributes. 
  4. Change the string length to 14 in the Language field.
  5. Choose Close.
  6. Choose Save and Deploy.
  7. From the following list, search one of technical names in the Repository Explorer.
    • SAP_GRL_IL_T_ModeOfTransport
    • SAP_GRL_IL_T_GHGEnergySourcingType
    • SAP_GRL_IL_T_GHGEnergyClassification
    • SAP_GRL_IL_T_GHGDataQualityCharacteristic
    • SAP_GRL_IL_T_GHGCategory
    • SAP_GRL_IL_T_GHGScope
  8. Choose Details in the top right corner > fx icon in the data flow > Language in Columns.
  9. Change the numbers in Length and Expression fields to 14 as shown in the following screen shot.

  10. Choose Save and Deploy.
  11. Repeat the steps 7 to 10 until all six objects are edited.

 

Issue 5 Filter Unavailable Due to Missing Hierarchy in the Data Source

Symptom

The filters in SAP Green Ledger Analytical Dashboard are unavailable due to missing hierarchy.

Procedure

  1. Open SAP Green Ledger Analytical Dashboard.
  2. Open the filter menu of the unavailable filter, select Edit Filter.
  3. Choose Flat Presentation hierarchy in the pop-up window.
  4. Choose OK.

 

Issue 6 Business Content Import Fails Due to Time Tables and Dimensions Error

Symptom

Business content import failed in SAP Analytics Cloud. This can be checked in Import Summary. To access Import Summary, see Access Import Summary from Monitor Page.

Procedure

  1. Open SAP Datasphere, in the side navigation area, choose Space Management, locate your space tile, and choose Edit to open it.
  2. In the Time Data section, choose Create Time Tables and Dimensions to open the dialog.
  3. Keep the default values unchanged.
  4. Choose Create. Please see Create Times Dimension or use the In-App Help directly in SAP Datasphere for more information.

entry.title: Complying to EUDR using SAP Ariba Supplier Management and SAP Green Token
entry.content:
Authors: Allan Soo, Sabrina Haller, Gloria Figaroa and Nike Klaubert

Complying to European Union Deforestation Regulation using SAP Ariba Supplier Management and SAP Green Token

Introduction

From the 30th of December 2025, large and medium-sized EU importers will be impacted by the European Union Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) requiring them to conduct both due diligence and track and trace activities to make sure that the commodity (produced after the date that the regulation comes into force) does not originate from a plot of land that has been cleared for commercial purposes. Initially announced from 29th of June 2023, the phase-in period gives companies time to prepare for the regulation.

What commodities and products are impacted?

EUDR declares that both raw commodities and products containing these commodities are subject to compliance. The commodities include:

  • Cattle, meat livestock and leather
  • Cocoa beans, cocoa powder (no sugar/sweeteners) and foods containing cocoa
  • Coffee
  • Palm oil and some of its derived products
  • Rubber, including tyres, conveyor belts and cords
  • Soya beans
  • Wood and timber, including pallets, kitchenware, printed paper, furniture and seats.

Based on these items, it becomes difficult to determine whether the item requires EUDR due diligence assessments. Purchasing activities from foreign countries requires determining whether the impacted commodity contains a product that is restricted from imports into the EU. Further details on these commodities can be viewed in the EUDR document, Annex I.

Who should be concerned?

Sourcing and procurement departments in the EU will need to begin implementing processes that conduct thorough due diligence and reporting activities to ensure that imported items are not subject to deforestation for commercial purposes.

 A large company, according to the EU Accounting Directive (2013/34/EU), would exceed two of the following:

  • Balance sheet total of €20,000,000
  • Net turnover of €40,000,000
  • Average number of employees of 250 for the financial year

For medium sized undertakings, the entity must not exceed two of the following:

  • Balance sheet total of €20,000,000
  • Net turnover of €40,000,000
  • Average number of employees of 250 for the financial year

The commission, furthermore, defines small undertakings as:

  • Firms with fewer than 50 employees for the financial year
  • Annual turnover or balance sheet below €10 million

And micro undertakings as:

  • Firms with fewer than 10 employees
  • With an annual turnover below €2 million for the financial reporting year.

EUDR reporting periods begin with large and medium enterprises from the 30th of December 2025, with small and micro enterprises beginning their reporting periods from 30th of June 2026. Any new item containing an EUDR commodity that is being placed onto the EU market from these dates will be subject to the regulation. Entities are to conduct their EUDR due diligence checks once every year and store these records.

What about Omnibus Proposal proposed by the EU Commission?

The proposed Omnibus package will not amend current planned obligations to existing and future reporting entities. Leaving EUDR largely intact.

Penalties for noncompliance?

Up to 4% of the importer’s annual turnover and confiscation of commodities or products if it is found to originate from a plot of land cleared for commercial purposes. For wood products, the exporter must have legally obtained the product for export into the EU.

Procurement’s role in addressing EUDR

Situations that require procurement to have processes in place for complying to EUDR includes purchasing a new item from any (existing or new) that contains a commodity or product that falls under Annex I of the EUDR document.

An example is the procurement of wooden office furniture, wooden pallets and chairs with SAP Ariba Sourcing and Buying, or using SAP S/4HANA to source soybeans and timber.

SAP’s solutions to complying with EUDR

SAP offers a range of sourcing, reporting and due diligence solutions to help customers comply to EUDR. SAP Green Token is designed to address Article 9 of EUDR, while SAP Ariba Supplier Risk provides assessment, risk mitigation and monitoring solutions – and aims to help customers comply to Articles 10 and 11. Fig. 1 provides an overview of the solutions SAP and partners offer to help customers comply to EUDR.

Figure 1: How SAP Ariba works with SAP’s solutions to manage and mitigate deforestation risks for sourced commodities and other products containing declared items. *Suitable partners can be found on store.sap.com by searching for “EUDR”. ** Custom Fields or Custom Risk Categories (GA 2408, see SAP Help - Custom Risk Categories / SAP Help - Enable Custom Risk Categories).

SAP Green Token and Article 9

SAP Green Token is a supply chain compliance cloud solution that enables accounting of sustainable material movements with segregation or mass balancing and tokenization for trust and compliance with recognized standards and regulations. The primary EUDR compliance capability is the use of segregated material accounting (Fig. 2) and management of the due diligence statements for EUDR.

Figure 2: Input-output track and traceability of raw commodity materials across the value chain with tokenised sustainability information to the final product.

SAP S/4HANA sourcing and PO order line-item creation leads to SAP Green Token journey for a commodity that is impacted by EUDR. The inbound claims (Fig. 3) and orders for the commodities should be supplemented with the sustainability information from the supplier proving that the commodity has not been sourced from deforested land.

Figure 3: Inbound records of the raw commodities that are being sourced into the EU within SAP Green Token solution.

Depending on whether the organization is the primary importer into the EU or an organization further downstream within the EU, the due diligence statement information is automatically uploaded into the EUDR Traces Database. Subsequently, the generated reference number is captured back into SAP Green Token.

The next step requires the exporter or processor to undergo the “conversion” of the material into a percentage of waste (Fig. 4), recycled content, EUDR commodity content, etc. that perseveres the tokenisation process. The tokenisation process converts the raw material into a digital asset containing sustainability information which can then be passed down the supply chain via segregated-balanced accounting. In this use case, you may purchase a piece of furniture that is 40% timber coming from a non-EU country. For outgoing deliveries, SAP Green Token can automatically share this information with customers via email.

Figure 4: Conversion process where the percentage of materials are classified based on certain sustainability attributes so that they are fully accounted for.

The compliance process is not complete, as Articles 10 and 11 of the regulation need to be complied to. For this, a risk mitigation, assessment and management solution are needed. This is where SAP Ariba Supplier Management comes in.

During the outbounds process in SAP Green Token, due diligence statements can be tracked with the dashboard which can be seen below in Fig. 5.

Figure 5: Outbounds process where the POs for materials, satellite JSON files and their attached statements can be monitored towards compliance.

Using SAP Ariba Supplier Risk to conduct deforestation due diligence

SAP Ariba Supplier Risk supports the buyer with risk assessment, risk mitigation and risk monitoring activities for EUDR (Article 10 and 11). The supplier’s data can be added to SAP Ariba Supplier Risk through synchronization with an integrated ERP system, supplier data file import or by supplier requests as part of the onboarding process in SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance. To assess the EUDR risk exposure, suppliers can be segmented based on the commodity to identify suppliers in scope of EUDR. The supplier’s data can then be screened with intelligent web crawling solutions and 3rd party data providers that can be integrated via custom fields using the risk category information risk category can be developed within SAP Ariba Supplier Risk as a part of a maximum of 25 custom risk categories to feed in this data. Fig. 6: shows the screening and risk categorisation of the suppliers in the solution.

Figure 6: Showing the number of suppliers that are low, medium and high risk at deforestation practices. Buyer then conducts due diligence on these suppliers through further questionnaire assessments.

To achieve a holistic EUDR risk view of the supplier, the engagement request feature can be leveraged to obtain additional EUDR specific information directly from Tier-1 suppliers. In this context, customers have the flexibility to create their own questionnaires with EUDR related questions. When selecting suppliers for assessments, factors such as the country’s: incidence for deforestation, rate of deforestation, reports and claims of deforestation, impacted indigenous peoples from land clearing, corruption/political indexes, supply chain and plots of land cleared, risk of the product being mixed with other commodities at risk of deforestation, and any FLEGT timber licenses (if applicable). This forms a part of the risk assessment process.

In case a concrete risk has been identified (e.g. a high deforestation risk), it can be addressed by creating a finding that is associated with the engagement request. The risk mitigation is supported by the application Findings and Event Collaboration in SAP Ariba Supplier Risk. A finding is raised, reviewed and assigned to internal and external stakeholders such as the supplier risk manager, external stakeholders like the individuals from the supplier’s organization or other external parties for example, NGOs or auditors. They can collaborate on analyzing the finding and execute an action plan, like requesting further information from the supplier and planning audits on sites to proactively mitigate the risk.

Embedding EUDR due diligence into purchasing processes

 Buyers must be aware of the deforestation risk of suppliers whenever they need to take a decision. By embedding the deforestation risk category in SAP Ariba Sourcing and SAP Ariba Contracts buyers can determine suppliers with a low deforestation risk in a sourcing event or award contracts to suppliers that are best aligned with their deforestation risk appetites.

Figure 7: Buyers can extract up to 25 custom risk scores (and create a deforestation risk score) from SAP Ariba Supplier Risk into the SAP Ariba Contracts workspace and SAP Ariba Sourcing, with guided sourcing capabilities (from left to right).

EU Observatory and other resources

The EU provides resources (such as the EU observatory on deforestation in Fig. 8 and 9) to help buyers and importers of EUDR commodities to track and identify high risk countries of concern based on satellite, forest imagery that is continuously updated.  Importers of the high risk EUDR commodity can determine deforestation rates via this portal. You may be wondering; how does an importer legally import any form of wood into the EU? Wood that is harvested after the 29th of June 2023 will need to adhere to the EU Timber Regulation (EUTR), which is a regulation that aims to prevent imports of illegally logged timber products.

The EU will have a benchmarking system designating countries that are standard, low or high risk which will guide buyers in conducting further EUDR due diligence activities. The publication of the risk country profiles is planned to be made available from 30th of June 2025 and an existing country classification list can be accessed here.

Figure 8: The EU’s deforestation observatory showing commercial land clearing deforestation coverage and trends.

Figure 9: EU’s Observatory mask showing deforestation metrics such as coverage and incidence rates.

These are some of the publicly available tools provided by the EU that helps buyers monitor activities for deforestation. The buyer can take these metrics and conduct further due diligence on new imports for EUDR commodities and products through SAP Ariba Supplier Risk, SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance Management, and SAP Green Token on a yearly basis.

Conclusion

Chief Sustainability, Compliance and Procurement Officers face new regulatory, cross-border challenges they need to address in a time where environmental regulations are altering their sourcing behaviours to protect ecosystems. To facilitate this level of compliance, automated reporting, supplier assessments, and material track and trace solutions are needed to mitigate both supplier and deforestation risks. Solutions and new processes need to be established to ensure prevent confiscation of goods and avert fines. SAP Ariba and partners can help you comply by offering solutions to conduct due diligence, track and trace, due diligence statement reporting and risk management.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) - Generate ESG Reports With AI Application
entry.content:
SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) has introduced an out-of-the-box functionality, Generate ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) reports with AI application. With the Generate ESG Reports with AI app, the ESG reporting process is automated across the selected periods. It uses the ESG data that has already been imported into SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) and creates the reports based on the imported data. The AI generated reports are available to download in the .pdf format.

In this blog, I will outline how to define the content for custom templates based on set of facts, i.e.,  available metrics or reference facts, and how to generate ESG reports by leveraging AI.

Mini Note:

If you want to understand the nitty-gritty of SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) out-of-the-box functionalities and its Integration with SAP EHSM-EM (Emission Management), check-out my blog posts listed below.

  1. European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) 
  2. SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Import Greenhouse Gas Emissions from SAP EHS Environment Management 
  3. Addendum to SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Import Greenhouse Gas Emissions from SAP EHSM-EM 
  4. SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) Metric Management-Basic Custom Metric & Standard Custom Metric 
  5. Exporting and Importing Custom Objects and CPE Packages in SAP Sustainability Control Tower 
  6. Managing Qualitative Metrics in SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) for ESRS and BRSR Framework 
  7. SAP S/4HANA EHS : Environment Management (Emissions Management) – Part:1 (Master Data Entities) 
  8. SAP S/4HANA EHS : Environment Management (Emissions Management) – Part:2 (Identifying & Preparing Compliance Requirement) 
  9. SAP S/4HANA EHS : Environment Management (Emissions Management) – Part:3 (Compliance Scenario Activities) 

 

Let us get started...why wait?...

Generate ESG Reports With AI Application

 

Let us take look at the "Prerequisites" before we dive in

  1. ESG specific data must have been imported into SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT)
  2. Must have the roles, i.e., SUS_SCT_AI_Reporting_Assistant_Manager & SUS_SCT_AI_Reporting_Assistant_Viewer

ESG Data Imported into Sustainability Control Tower

 

For instance, I have created a template named "ESG Report Template for Calcination & Power"  to generate an ESG report for the above imported data using the AI application.

ESG Report Template for Calcination & Power Business Lines

 

let us use the "Create"  option to set-up a tailored custom template for ESG metrics and reference facts.  For Instance, I have added sections and subsections to align with the ESG pillars to have the template structure. We can rename, remove the sections and subsections at any point of time.

Sections and Subsections of ESG report

 

Now, let us start filling the sections with the content. To add the text to the "carbon emissions profile" , I have built the content by adding "Reference Facts" and " Metrics". We can add maximum 30 facts for each section or subsection.

Pillar: Environment

We can choose the "Reference facts" from the predefined facts, and metrics can be chosen from the available SAP provided quantitative metrics. The text  in this section will be generated by AI (Artificial Intelligence) for the metrics defined in the "Manage Metrics App".

Assignment of Reference Facts & Metrics to generate text for the Carbon Emissions Profile

 

Now, let us use the option " Generate" to preview the content for the above assigned reference facts and metrics.

 

AI generated text for the Carbon Emissions Profile

 

Now, let us generate charts for the "Carbon Emissions Profile". 

 

 

Following the successful assignment of the charts, use the option "Generate" charts for each metric.

 

AI generated graph for the GHG Emissions by GHG Scope & Business Locations

 

AI generated graph for the GHG Emissions by Business Country

 

AI generated graph for the Location & Market based Emissions

 

Now, let us create tables to fill out emissions metrics details by leveraging AI. Use the option " Add Table" to assign the required metrics tables.

For Instance, I have chosen two tables to represent  GHG Emissions (CO2e) & GHG Emissions Reduction Targets (CO2e).

 

 

Following the successful addition of the tables, use the option "Generate" to fill out the details for the selected table.

AI generated table for Scope-1 Emissions

 

AI generated table for Scope-2 & Scope-3 Emissions

 

In a similar manner, let us assign the reference facts and metrics to generate text , charts and tables for the "Energy Profile" under "Environmental" pillar.

 

AI generated text for the Energy Profile

 

AI generated tables for the Energy Profile

 

In a similar manner, let us assign the reference facts and metrics to generate text , charts and tables for the "Water Profile" under "Environmental" pillar.

 

AI generated text for the Water Profile

 

AI generated chart for Water Usage by Business Country

 

  AI generated chart for Water Usage Over Time

 

Pillar: Social

In a similar manner, let us assign the reference facts and metrics to generate text , charts and tables for the "Health & Safety" under the "Social" pillar.

 

AI generated text for the Health & Safety facts

 

AI generated graph for the work related incidents & fatalities

 

Pillar: Governance

In a similar manner, let us assign the reference facts and metrics to generate text , charts and tables for the "Governance Body" under the "Governance" pillar.

 

AI generated text for the governance body metrics

 

AI generated graph for the metric share of the women in management

 

AI generated graph for the Anti-Corruption Incidents metrics

 

Following the successful setup of the sections and subsections for the ESG reporting content, let us take a look at the configured report content preview. Let us use the option "Preview" to understand the structure of the ESG report.

 

 

Now, let us generate the ESG report  using the tailored custom template. 

 

Once the details have been provided to generate the report using the tailored custom template,  select the "Generate Report" option.

 

While the ESG report is being generated, system displays the progress of the report.

 

Once the system generates the report, its status is updated as "Completed".

Let us select the option "Download" to view the ESG report in Pdf format.

The ESG report has been downloaded in .pdf format.

 

 

Here we go....

AI generated ESG report - SAP SCT

 

 

😊 This brings me to the end of the process walk-through of the creation of the custom ESG template and AI usage to generate tailored ESG report for a specific sustainability reporting year. I hope my blog proves useful to the sustainability team. I look forward to leveraging AI capabilities at scale to strengthen ESG reporting structures.

 

--

Yours Sincerely,

Pardhasaradhi Reddy.C

entry.title: Where finance and carbon unite (Part 1)
entry.content:
Where finance and carbon unite: A focus on the integration between Sustainability Footprint Management, Sustainability Data Exchange, SAP Green Ledger and SAP S/4HANA

Integration has always been at the heart of my story telling approach and hopefully comes across in my blogs. In this blog, I'll explore how this theme connects various solutions like Sustainability Footprint Management with its detailed product footprint calculations, its integration with our core SAP S/4HANA Suite, and our latest innovation, the 'Green Ledger,' which unites finance and carbon accounting.

I'll illustrate these points using an example: how everything fits together when we manufacture a windshield.

  • I shall begin with a high level overview of the setup in SAP S/4HANA; I shall focus on the future enhancements on this space (Universal Component Breakdown UCB) in a separate blog which allows for a more granular breakdown of the product, not only the breakdown of cost components but also a breakdown of quantities (carbon to start with).
  • Then I shall delve into the detailed product footprint calculation capabilities offered by Sustainability Footprint Management (SFM). As I explore the purchase of raw materials, we shall see how we can obtain the carbon footprint directly from suppliers through Sustainability Data Exchange (SDX) or derive them from Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) databases. This is where we have some gen AI capabilities which help you to map the product or product groups to emission factors thereby streamlining the process and improving accuracy. I shall then demonstrate how these values seamlessly integrate with SAP S/4HANA, enabling businesses to make more informed sourcing decisions by considering the carbon impact alongside traditional cost factors. This integration empowers organizations to optimize their supply chain while minimizing their environmental footprint. Finally, I shall also model the energy flows in the manufacturing plant to calculate a detailed product footprint for the manufactured material.
  • Subsequently, all material movements (goods receipts, goods issues) from SAP S/4HANA are then integrated with SAP Green Ledger. Here, financial dimensions are enriched with carbon information derived from Sustainability Footprint Management.

This is a schematic representation of the solution landscape for the blog:

Let's address this step by step: I have worked as a Group controller for an Automotive component supplier, so I'll begin with an example that I am familiar with: the manufacture of windshields.

 Please note that this is a highly simplified example with fictional values for the components and production processes.

1. Manufacturing set-up in SAP S/4HANA

The production of a windshield undergoes the following steps: First, raw glass is procured from a supplier and cut to the desired shape. The edges are then ground using a grinding machine, and holes are drilled. Following these initial steps, the glass is washed and dried before logos are printed onto its surface. To achieve the correct curvature, the glass undergoes heat treatment in a furnace. After this, the glass is washed and dried once again before it is assembled with a PVB sheet. The assembled piece is then processed through an autoclave, which functions similarly to a pressure cooker, to enhance the glass's transparency. Finally, the windshield goes through a thorough inspection process. Upon passing inspection, the pre-assembly of additional components such as mirror brackets or camera supports can start. This marks the first stage of the windshield production.

I have modeled this process in SAP S/4HANA as a semi-integrated line, utilizing blue boxes to represent "work centers" or production lines.

The focus of this blog is on our sustainability narrative, so I will not delve into the production setup or costing details. However, I would like to highlight an important innovation being developed by our Product Engineering teams called “Universal Component Breakdown”:

The breakdown of a product or a service into its origin in various dimensions across multiple production/service levels within a company.

This is based upon a functionality which we already have in Product Costing called the “cost component split” which comes in two flavours – the production cost component split and the primary cost component split. In addition to a new and improved cost breakdown, our teams are also working on a “quantity breakdown” wherein the Product Costing application is enhanced to determine the GHG emissions in the standard cost estimate and can be rolled up along the value chain, in the same way that standard costs are rolled up for a manufactured product in a multi-level cost estimate. This functionality is how we approach the carbon accounting from a “bottom-up” perspective.

The “Universal Component Breakdown (UCB)”, which is a future successor of the cost component split  forms the basis of carbon sub-ledgers, has “Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA)” as a pre-requisite(as per current planning, but subject to change) , and I shall address this topic in a separate blog post.

I have kept my example simple, focusing primarily on “carbon” and product carbon footprint calculation.

However, in real life, there are more aspects related to sustainability that should be considered. For instance, one must ask questions such as:

  • How am I handling the glass that falls off as I cut my windshield to shape? Typically, these would be recycled back into the Flat Glass Production process.
  • How am I managing water usage in my cleaning process? Recycled water could be used, and this is something that should be measured and reported on.

All these considerations are crucial for a comprehensive approach to sustainability.

2. Calculation of the Product Footprints

When it comes to understanding the total environmental impact of a product, we need to consider the environmental impact at each of the following stages:

  • Upstream processes
  • Transformation processes within our plant
  • Downstream processes

This structured approach ensures a comprehensive assessment of the product's overall environmental footprint.

The emissions included in the product carbon footprint calculation are:

  • Upstream processes:
    • Raw material purchase and pre-processing (Scope 3.1)
    • Inbound transport (Scope 3.4)
  • Processing in our production facility:
    • Direct Emissions from owned or controlled sources (Scope 1)
    • Indirect Emissions from purchased energy consumed (Scope 2)
    • Upstream emissions of purchased fuel, electricity, transmission and distribution losses (Scope 3.3)
    • Production Waste (Scope 3.5)
  • Downstream processes:
    • Transport to final customer if paid by the manufacturer (Scope 3.4)
    • Downstream transport if paid by the customer (Scope 3.9)
    • Processing of sold products (Scope 3.10)
    • Use of sold products (Scope 3.11)
    • End of Life treatment (Scope 3.12)

In this blog, I will limit the scope of the footprint calculation to a cradle-to-gate scenario and consider the emissions related to Scope 3.1, Scope 1 and Scope 2 for simplicity. This means my focus will be on the upstream processes and the transformation within our production unit, which will define the boundary conditions of this analysis.

 I highly recommend blogs written by Nico if you would like to deep dive into our solution. You will find many insightful articles in the following link: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q2-24 Upd... - SAP Community

 Let's begin with the upstream process (Scope 3.1 emissions):

In my example, I am purchasing raw glass, mirror brackets, and camera supports to manufacture my windshield. These components could be sourced from various suppliers. Additionally, the Finance department is often responsible for considering sustainability metrics when procuring raw materials, with the aim of reducing the product's environmental footprint.

The footprint information of the components can be obtained in the following ways:

  • Suppliers can directly provide CO2e emissions data.
  • CO2e emissions data can be sourced from Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) databases.
  • Additionally, a custom dataset can be developed by considering multiple LCA values, which can then be used to determine the emission factors.

What is Sustainability Data Exchange (SDX)?

It is solution specifically designed to securely exchange standardized sustainability data, including product footprints, along the value chain. 

It is a part of the SAP Business Network and uses the carbon data interoperability standards established by the Partnership for Carbon Transparency (PACT) hosted by the World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD). The solution also draws on SAP’s experience as a founding member of Catena-X and Confinity-X, where the program set the first technical specifications for the standardized exchange of carbon emissions data, allowing different emissions and accounting technology solutions to connect to and effectively share sustainability information.

SAP offers this Business network to onboard and interact with the SAP ecosystem, however, if your suppliers have other certified solutions which follow the Catena-X and PACT standards, you can connect inter-operably with those solutions to get the emission data from the suppliers

a. Use case 1: Emission factors obtained directly from suppliers

 Sustainability Data Exchange (SDX) helps you to share product carbon footprint data with business partners across your business network based on interoperable and standardized data models. It enables exchange of Scope 3 product footprint information between connected partners via a request/respond feature.

Purchasing entity Perspective:

The purchasing entity can electronically request carbon footprint data from its suppliers via the SDX platform. On my homepage, there are dedicated apps that allow me to send requests to my suppliers (Manage Inbounds) and receive requests from my customers (Manage Outbounds), facilitating the exchange of carbon footprint information.

Please note that this blog does not cover the setup process. Instead, it focuses on the perspective of the business user who will be utilizing this solution. From the purchasing entity’s perspective, I can log on to SDX and send a “form-based request” to my supplier to provide the product footprint (in different standards: for example, WBSCD, PACT, CATENA-X). Once the request is sent, the status will indicate that a footprint has been requested from the supplier.

Supplier Side:

Suppliers can maintain detailed product footprints of the components they sell within SDX, as illustrated below. As mentioned earlier, if your suppliers use any other certified solutions which follow the CATENA-X and PACT protocols, we can also integrate with them.

They would receive requests to provide their carbon footprint data. For instance, my supplier ZPR_V01 has connected to SDX and can see that I have requested this footprint information from them.

They can then submit their response digitally based on the “response” feature.

After a supplier submits footprint data, it is integrated into SFM via an API and pending review for release. Once approved, the supplier's footprint can be used to calculate the product's footprint inventory. In my case, I have already procured Raw Glass 1 from two suppliers and can now view the aggregated footprint for the product. In addition, you can also accept and decline incoming data in case you are doubtful of the figures or you are not happy with the data sources.  

These footprints can then be integrated back into SAP S/4HANA where this can be used to drive informed decision-making by incorporating sustainability indicators in our sourcing process.

If you are wondering why there are differing CO2e rates for the supplier ZPR_V01 (where I maintained 7,165 kgCO2e/kg of the product in SFM, compared to 2,866 kgCO2e in the screenshot above), the differing CO2e rates for supplier ZPR_V01 can be attributed to a unit of measure (UoM) conversion. While the CO2e is maintained in kilograms (kg), the product's UoM is in pieces. Since purchasing is done in pieces, there's a conversion from pieces to kg based on the material master's UoM conversion factor. This explains why the CO2e rate is 7,165 kgCO2e/kg in SFM, compared to 2,866 kgCO2e in the above screenshot.

b. Use case 2: Emission factors obtained from LCA databases

If the supplier cannot provide us with emission factor data, we can source it from official Emission Factors or Lifecycle Assessment (LCA) databases. We readily integrate data from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), DEFRA, EMBER and have partnerships with organizations like Ecoinvent, Carbonminds who provide the data in the required format. Additionally, we can upload data from other LCA databases by mapping it to the necessary format

In my example, I created a custom package and uploaded it into Sustainability Footprint Management (SFM). SFM offers two upload options for creating a custom package:

  • Simple Template: This is a streamlined version designed for essential information, ideal for simple use cases or testing purposes.
  • LCA Template: This is a more detailed option, offering flexibility by organizing information across multiple tabs.

Once this is done, I can then use AI to automatically generate emission factor mappings for my products or product groups without footprint. This is a huge time saver given the volumetry of data we need to deal with.

The similarity score is determined by three key parameters: the similarity of the product's name or description to the emission factor description (both short and long versions), the product's commodity code, and the product's country code, which is derived based on where it is sourced from.  

Let's continue with the production processes in our plant and the calculation of Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions associated with this:

Step 1: Managing source data

The first step in calculating the carbon footprint of our windshields involves extracting relevant data from our core ERP system - both master and transactional, and integrating it into Sustainability Footprint Management (SFM), the solution which is used to calculate the product carbon footprint (PCF). Once a connection has been set up between the S4 and SFM, the “Manage Replications ” app can be used to import all relevant master data from the core S4 system to SFM.  You can select the data object you want to import, start or schedule the replication. Additionally, an import using data files or API is also available if you are working with a non-integrated system.

In my case, I verified the imported master data to ensure my materials, work centers and activities have been imported correctly

  • Master Data:
    • Products: The specific products for which I am calculating the product carbon footprint.
    • Resources: The different work centers used in production
    • Activities: Activities that need to be considered in the calculation of the product footprint. In this example, I am calculating emissions based on machine run time and set-up time.
    • Cost centers: After replicating the cost centers, you can assign each cost center to the appropriate production line. This will enable the SAP Green Ledger to accurately track and make sense of energy-related postings

For example, in the figure below, you can see the different work centers/production lines and their corresponding cost center assignments.

  • Transactional Data:

During the production process, the following data is recorded in the core S/4 system and subsequently   imported into SFM in a periodic and aggregated manner:

  • Resources used in the production process: Documented through Activity Declarations or Service Confirmations.
  • Component consumption: Tracked via Goods Issued to Production.
  • Finished goods declarations: Noted through Goods Receipt from Production.
  • Goods receipts from suppliers, Goods issues to customers, etc etc

Here is a screenshot illustrating how a 'Goods Issue for Production' import appears in SFM.

Here is a screenshot illustrating how an ‘Activity declaration’ or ‘internal service confirmation’ import appears in SFM

I will calculate the emissions from the consumption of electricity during the machine's operation and setup, as well as the emissions associated with the components consumed, to determine the total emissions for the finished goods assembly.

Step 2: Defining organizational boundaries

The subsequent step involves defining the scope and organizational boundaries for footprint calculation. At this stage, I've selected certain parts of the production value chain to be included in the footprint calculation. Currently, the following are factored in:

  • Purchased product footprint related to raw material acquisition (Scope 3.1)
  • Direct emissions and energy consumption used in production (Scope 1 and Scope 2)

To expand the footprint calculation in the future, I could incorporate:

  • Purchased and internal product transportation (Scope 3.4)
  • Emissions generated from “waste from operations” gathered via a forms-based data collection method.

Additionally, we can model any activity for which we aim to calculate Scope 1, Scope 2, and Scope 3 emissions as a “Business Activity.” We can then use a form-based data collection method to enter data and compute the corresponding emissions. One example of such an activity is business travel undertaken by project leaders working on a product prototype.

For instance, glass breakage could be recycled in the float process or sent to a landfill with corresponding emissions associated with this. The ability to refine the footprint calculation at a later stage gives customers flexibility to tailor the assessment to their specific needs and priorities, often starting small before getting to a full-fledged footprint calculation.

Step 3: Creating an Energy flow model

This step involves creating an energy flow model that maps energy consumption and distribution within your organization. This model connects energy carriers (Electricity, Fuel, Gas) with their respective sources (e.g., specific energy providers) and links them to resources (production lines/work centers) or facilities (plant, warehouse).

 Types of Energy used:

The various types of energy used are modeled as "Energy Carriers". In my example, there are two energy carriers:

  • Electricity
  • Gas

Energy Providers:

In my example, there are two energy providers:

  • EDF (Electricité de France) for Electricity
  • Engie for Gas

A contract between the legal entity and the utility (energy) provider (such as gas or electricity) is modeled as an "Energy Source" within SFM. EDF offers a choice between classical energy and renewable energy. Therefore, two separate contracts with EDF can be represented as individual "Energy Sources" in SFM. Similarly, Engie offers green gas as an option, which can also be modeled as an Energy Source in SFM.

Additionally, the cost center where energy invoices are posted before being allocated to production work centers can be assigned to these Energy Sources. This facilitates seamless integration with the SAP Green Ledger.

 Production Process: The production process is modeled as a semi-integrated line with the following key work centers:

  1. Furnace: This is an integrated line where cutting, grinding, drilling, washing, printing and heat treatment happen. Heat treatment being an energy-intensive process, this line has a dedicated electricity meter.
  2. Laminated Line: The PVB assembly is carried out in this line, which also has a separate electricity meter due to its high energy consumption.
  3. Quality and Pre-assembly: Quality control and pre-assembly of mirror brackets and camera supports happen here. These lines do not have dedicated meters and are covered by one common electricity meter.

Although my example focuses on the transformation of glass, it is important to note that the most energy-intensive process is not the transformation itself, but rather the production of the raw glass in the floats.

Energy Metering and Allocation:

There are four electricity meters:

  • One each for the "Furnace" and "Lamination" production lines, one for the “Quality” and “Pre-assembly” lines and finally one for the overall plant facility.
  • Energy consumption in the "Furnace" and "Lamination" lines is directly allocated to the products passing through these lines.
  • Energy consumption to the "Quality" and "Pre-assembly" production lines are split based on the relative machine run time and set up of these work centers.
  • Other Electricity used at the plant level does not go to the product carbon footprint, but rather to the corporate carbon footprint.

I have modeled the energy flows with meters, but there are multiple approaches to modeling energy flow in your plant, including:

Scenario 1: Energy Modeling Based on Planned Energy Consumption Rates

If your plant lacks energy meters for each production line, you can allocate energy bills based on the proportion of time each machine runs. Initially, you need to input the energy consumption rate per unit of time for each machine runs. The system then uses the actual activity declaration for each production order to calculate and distribute energy consumption accordingly.

Scenario 2: Energy Modeling Based on Meters

In this scenario, each resource (or production line/work center) has an associated energy meter. These meters provide energy consumption data, which can be linked to the number of hours a machine has run in producing a specific product. This data is then used to allocate CO2e for carbon footprint calculations across the production chain.

 Scenario 3: Energy Modeling Based on Meters and Planned Consumption Rates

In some cases, you might want to distribute energy consumption based on a combination of meters and planned consumption rates. This approach is useful when energy meters are only available for part of the organization.

Step 4 :  Creating a Footprint Inventory Scope

Upon importing the transactional data, energy meter readings, and any additional form-based information required, we shall then calculate a periodic footprint inventory for the entities within our organizational scope using the 'Calculate Footprint App'.

Once the footprint is calculated, you can drill down into the footprint results to see the detailed breakdown of all calculated footprint items, including products, suppliers, and more, as illustrated below:

Let's examine the footprint calculation in the first step of our production process:
