In a real-world scenario, a windshield would have a more significant carbon footprint; however, the example provided here is a fictional and simplified one. Nonetheless, as expected, raw glass makes the largest contribution to the overall carbon footprint. The windshield's composition involves two different glass thicknesses, leading to variations in individual CO2E contributions. The energy consumption from the furnace is allocated to this production order. Within the production cost center, there are three activities (or resources): machine hours, setup time, and labor. The allocation of energy is based solely on machine hours and setup time, excluding labor. This explains why two of the activities have associated CO2E values, while the third does not.

In addition to the Sankey diagram, which visually breaks down emissions by components and processes, we are also introducing a new feature: a 'flat itemization.' This feature, to be released in the coming weeks, provides a quick overview of the materials consumed and resources used in the production of a product, along with their corresponding emissions

I can analyze the entire production value chain, from start to finish, to precisely assess the carbon footprint and pinpoint CO2 equivalent (CO2E) impacts at various stages, for example:

  • How much carbon emissions are caused by one supplier compared to another?
  • Which production line is the most energy-intensive? What kinds of improvements can be made across the line to enhance energy efficiency?

These are actionable insights which translate to process improvements:

  • Comparing carbon emissions among different suppliers to identify greener alternatives.
  • Identifying the most energy-intensive production lines and recommending improvements across the line to enhance energy efficiency.

Once we have identified and set up our Opex/capex projects to improve the process, we can then closely monitor and track the energy consumption reductions. In addition, we can also share the footprint of our finished goods using SDX with our customers, just as we requested this information from our suppliers. 

We also offer comprehensive standard reports that provide an overview of all emissions within a company. These reports include:

  • A summary of the inflow and outflow of emissions for the specified period.
  • A detailed breakdown of emissions categorized according to the Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Protocol.
  • The top five products with the highest emissions, whether purchased, sold, or otherwise.
  • Identification of the highest energy consumers, including production lines, facilities, and process infrastructure.
  • A split of emissions by energy source, enabling quick tracking of the proportion of green electricity and green gas, particularly if specific targets have been set for these elements.

As a summary, we have addressed the following questions in this blog:

  1. How can we electronically request supplier footprint information?
  2. How can we incorporate this footprint into purchasing processes within the core ERP system for effective decision-making?
  3. How can we leverage actual production data—such as machine hours, setup time, energy consumption, and energy bills—to accurately model and calculate a carbon footprint at the product level, instead of relying on averages or cost-based data for your Environmental Product Declaration?
  4. How can we electronically share these calculated footprints of manufactured products with your customers?
  5. What kind of reports are available out of the box to accelerate carbon reporting ?

In the next blog, I am very excited to talk about our latest offering, “SAP Green Ledger,” which unites finance and carbon accounting. I shall talk about how data from Sustainability Footprint Management gets integrated into SAP Green ledger and the integration with SAP Green ledger facilitates the conversion of these footprints into financial journal entries, enabling a holistic and integrated approach to sustainability.

entry.title: Connecting Excel to SAP Sustainability Control Tower's API via Power Query
entry.content:
Introduction

Connecting Excel to the SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) allows for real-time data retrieval, enabling efficient ESG report creation and deep analysis. Given the effort involved in compiling data into SCT, having seamless access within Excel can significantly enhance productivity. This simplified example demonstrates how to connect Excel to SCT's outbound API using Power Query, specifically retrieving Scope 1 Emissions data for 2023. Once set up, refreshing the data in Excel ensures it is consistently up to date.

SCT Outbound APIs

SAP Sustainability Control Tower provides two key APIs: Metrics and Measures. These APIs enable access to all sustainability-related data.

  • Metrics API: Provides granular sustainability data metrics. API Overview
  • Measures API: Offers aggregated measures for sustainability monitoring. API Overview

For a deeper understanding of Metrics and Measures, visit SAP Community Overview.

Subscribing to API Service in SAP BTP Cockpit

Access your SAP BTP cockpit, navigate to your subaccount and complete the following steps:

  1. Go to the Instances and Subscriptions tab and choose Create.
  2. In the dialog box, select the SAP Sustainability Control Tower solution (sct-service-api) from the Services dropdown.
  3. Choose standard (Instance) from the Plan dropdown list and enter the required details as described in Creating Service Instances in Cloud Foundry.
  4. Create a service key as described in Service Keys.

After the successful set-up you should be able to view the key of the instance and also the clientid and clientsecret which will be important for later.

Testing in Business Accelerator Hub

Verifying API access is crucial for understanding data format and method interactions. Test connections at /GET GhgEmissions in the Business Accelerator Hub. Configure a new environment to match access specifications.

Specify the clientid and clientsecret and also the Landscape and Subdomain of your tenant. From the Landscape and the Subdomain then the Token URL is created which is required for the OAuth 2.0 authorization. OAuth 2.0 is utilized for secure authorization, exchanging credentials (client ID and secret) for access tokens used to authenticate API requests.

 

Once you have configured the environment you can Run the API calls in the Business Accelerator Hub.

Excel + PowerQuery Setup

To get data through Excel:

  1. Go to Data > Get Data > From Other Sources > Blank query > Advanced Editor.

Queries Setup

GetAccessToken Query

let

    // Replace these placeholders with your actual client ID and secret
    client_id = "ENTER YOUR CLIENT ID HERE",
    client_secret = "ENTER YOU CLIENT SECRET HERE", 

    // Create the body for the token request
    body = "grant_type=client_credentials&client_id=" & client_id & "&client_secret=" & client_secret,

    // Request token from the token URL
    tokenResponse = Json.Document(Web.Contents("ENTER TOKEN URL HERE",
        [
            Headers = [#"Content-Type"="application/x-www-form-urlencoded"],
            Content = Text.ToBinary(body)
        ])),

    access_token = tokenResponse[access_token]

in

    access_token

GetData Query

let

    AccessToken = GetAccessToken, // Name of the first query where you obtain the access token   

    ApiUrl = "https://eu20.sct.sustainability.cloud.sap/api/sct-analytics-service/v1/sustainabilityMetrics/GhgEmissions?$filter=periodId%20in%20('202301'%2C%20'202302'%2C%20'202303'%2C%20'202304'%2C%20'202305'%2C%20'202306'%2C%20'202307'%2C%20'202308'%2C%20'202309'%2C%20'202310'%2C%20'202311'%2C%20'202312')%20and%20scopeId%20eq%20'1'%20and%20dataTypeId%20eq%20'EMISSION'", // Prefiltered API URL for 2023 Scope 1 Emissions

    JsonResponse = Web.Contents(ApiUrl, [

        Headers = [
            #"Authorization" = "Bearer " & AccessToken
        ]
    ]),

    Data = Json.Document(JsonResponse)

in

 Please note that storing clientid and clientsecret directly in Power Query is convenient but can be risky if the Excel file is shared. Ensure files are stored securely and access is limited to trusted users.

Once you have specified both Queries, you should see the following response. The data is stored in a list and requires further drill down, converting to table and Expansion:

 

 

Then the Power Query Editor can be closed and the data loaded and you can see the loaded data in the GetData tab. You can easily further filter on the data, create Pivots or re-use the data. With a click on “Refresh All” you can easily update the data.  

 

Keep in mind that SCT APIs return up to 1000 records per batch. For datasets exceeding this limit, you must follow @nextLink to iteratively fetch all data pages.

By following all of the above steps, colleagues can establish Excel connectivity to SCT, enhancing their ability to access, re-use and analyze sustainability data effectively.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q2-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment
  • Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates
  • Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER
  • Simplified Data Integration
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Catena-X Certification
  • SAP Innovation Award Wins: Harting and Matsumoto Precision
  • Customer Success Story: DMK
  • SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Learning Journey: PCF Calculation

 

Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment

When integrating SAP Sustainability Footprint Management with various SAP systems, you often face a data challenge: Your warehouse in one SAP solution might be a facility in another or even a resource elsewhere. This inconsistency complicates footprint calculations, energy flow modeling, and linking environmental results to financials.

To address this and streamline and simplify the management of location data, we released the new Manage Locations application. This app serves as a single source for managing all locations, regardless of origin or business context. It addresses the need to reconcile and correlate locations that may have different semantics across multiple SAP solutions. With this new app you can:

  • View and manage all locations in one consolidated interface
  • Manually create locations or view those imported from other SAP modules
  • Easily distinguish between manually created and imported locations via the user interface
  • Navigate via links between imported location records and their corresponding system-generated system entries

Alternatively to replicating locations from source systems or creating them manually, you can upload location information via Excel files in the Import Master Data app. When importing, the software automatically generates corresponding location records that appear in the Manage Locations app – ensuring no duplicated or orphaned records. The locations itself are categorized into different location types, adding business context: Meter, Process Infrastructure, and Facility. Imported locations are automatically mapped to one of these three types. If a location type doesn’t match, it defaults to Facility. For modeling energy flows, you can now use these harmonized locations and resources as elements in your models. Hence, the creation of meters, process infrastructures, and facilities within the Model Energy Flows app is now managed exclusively via the new Manage Locations app – ensuring data consistency across apps.

Another major improvement is the possibility to assign cost centers for financial transparency and connecting carbon footprint results directly with your financial reporting. These assignments are time-dependent, ensuring correct mapping for each period. After calculating your organizational footprint, the Manage Footprint Results app shows the active cost center for that location – specifically, the cost center that is valid as of the calculation period’s start date, which is important if multiple cost centers are assigned to the location. Besides locations, cost centers can now also be assigned to energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. This enables better tracking of spending related to energy use and maintenance, helping to analyze and manage energy costs more effectively.

Click the picture to start the video:

Manage Locations App (Click to start video)

To summarize, these enhancements bring you a centralized, consistent interface for all location data with improved usability and a simplified integration across various SAP systems. The flexible cost center assignment enables the linkage of environmental data to financial entities. This empowers smarter and holistic decision-making in sustainability management, moving further along the journey towards ledger-based carbon accounting with SAP Green Ledger. For all details, see Manage Locations on SAP Help.

 

Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates

A common challenge for calculating Scope 1 and 2 emissions is the timely availability of energy bills needed for accurately recording energy consumption. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management addresses this by introducing more flexibility in how energy data can be captured. Now, when creating energy sources, you can select your preferred method for recording energy consumption, with the two available options:

  • Actual Consumption from Energy Bills: Enter the actual quantities consumed as detailed on your energy bills (the most accurate method).
  • Estimates via Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates: Add up amounts based on assigned meter readings and planned energy consumption rates, which allows you to work with estimates when bills are unavailable.

Select Recording of Energy Consumption

This new functionality isn’t limited to newly created energy sources. You can apply it to existing ones as well. However, it’s important to note that updating an energy source with this new logic doesn’t automatically trigger updates across all footprint inventories. If you edit the inventories that reference the updated energy source in their energy flow models, the system will recalculate using the newly selected consumption recording logic.

This release gives you the flexibility to maintain complete and more timely energy consumption records, improving the reliability of your sustainability data even when actual energy bills are delayed or not available at all. For more information, see the Energy Sources section under Model Energy Flows.

 

Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER

For calculating carbon footprints with no actual supplier or provider data available, it’s crucial to have access to reliable industry average data from Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) databases. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management provides you with the flexibility to upload respective data from any source into the Manage Emission Factors app. To simplify the setup for you and reduce manual efforts, we now added new default content, available for mapping your activities for calculating the respective footprints.

The data from UK Department for Energy Security and Net Zero and UK Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (UK DEFRA) includes emission factors for energy use, water consumption, waste disposal, recycling, and transport activities. There are datasets available for the years 2015 to 2024.

EMBER, an independent energy think tank, provides emission factors for electricity generation for over 200 geographies. The datasets comprise the years 2015 to 2023.

Click the picture to start the video:

Default Emission Factors in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management (Click to start video)

With those enhancements, you have access to additional reliable and diverse data sources for better environmental impact analysis and decision-making. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data.

This new content complements the datasets from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) which were already added last year. And for the second half year we plan to add even more pre-configured emission factors from additional sources, further enhancing your carbon footprint calculation. The addition of emission factors was also one of the highest voted items on SAP Influence, requested by several customers and partners. Thanks to your valuable feedback, we’re constantly improving our product.

 

Simplified Data Integration

SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduced significant enhancements to how sustainability data is imported and managed, making processes more simple, efficient, and user-friendly. The tool leverages the sustainability data integration service to streamline data import from SAP systems, including SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP Environment, Health and Safety Management. This update eliminates many manual steps and unifies the process across systems. All changes are reflected in the updated SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Implementation Guide on SAP Help Portal.

With those enhancements, we’re also introducing the Manage Replications application. This new app allows you to configure and manage the replication of master data objects, such as products or suppliers, from multiple integrated SAP systems. Once replication is initiated through this app, imported data becomes visible in the Import Master Data app, simplifying subsequent data management tasks. The key benefits for you are:

  • Multi-source replication: Import master data from various source systems (for example fetch Products from SAP S/4HANA and Suppliers from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition).
  • Centralized management: Oversee and control all data replications from one place.
  • Improved data consistency: Ensures data is harmonized and consistent, provided the correct source systems are chosen for each data object.
  • Filter records: For some of the entities, like Products, you can filter the source data objects so only the ones which are relevant in your footprint calculation are replicated.

To use the Manage Replications app, users must be manually assigned the roles: SUS_Replication_Viewer or SUS_Replication_Expert. Find further information as well as all details on the new app in SAP Help: Manage Replications.

Manage Replications App

For existing customers, the following changes are required:

  • Switch to Manage Replications App: The previous method of importing master data directly within the Import Master Data app is discontinued for integrated source systems. The Import button has been removed, and all such imports must now be managed through the new Manage Replications app.
  • SAP EHS Management Integration: All emissions management activities and locations must now be imported via the Manage Replications app.
  • Replication Details: When replicating Suppliers or Emission Management Activities, each replication now performs a complete import – incremental or delta updates are no longer supported for these entities.

Those updates vastly improve the efficiency and governance of sustainability data management within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, offering you a more powerful, secure, and streamlined experience when handling master data from multiple integrated sources.

 

Other Release Highlights

The Monitor Plausibility Checks app displays reference details of the item, period, and measure value used as the baseline for creating relative plausibility alerts. This helps you assess how much actual results deviate from expected calculations. For more information, see Monitor Plausibility Checks. This is also a feature that was implemented after numerous customers requested it via SAP Influence.

A new Generate Records button in the Manage Purchased Products Footprints app allows you to manually generate records for purchased products and product groups that lack footprints. Progress is displayed during record generation, and users are notified if records need to be regenerated due to data updates, ensuring accuracy and control. Additionally, the UI in the related tabs now labels the AI-assisted mapping button as Generate Mappings Using AI. See Manage Purchased Product Footprints for more details.

We achieved significant performance improvements in cycle calculations, where a process's output becomes its own input. Previously, the runtime increased with the cycle's complexity. Now, calculations are done in-memory rather than relying on database access, greatly reducing calculation time and improving user efficiency.

SAP now offers real-time machine translation for documentation on the SAP Help Portal, including SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This increases the number of available languages, improving accessibility and availability of product information for users worldwide.

To help you with onboarding and using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we’re also constantly enhancing the product documentation on SAP Help. In the previous quarter, this included the following topics:

  • Energy carrier assignment per internal service confirmation: The new topic in the Energy Distribution Scenarios section explains two different methods for assigning energy to production documents using data from internal service confirmations, see Energy Carrier Assignment per Internal Service Confirmation.
  • Modeling consistent energy flows: Useful guidance on using energy elements in flow models and explanations on how different components are connected, see Modeling Consistent Energy Flows.
  • Energy distribution scenarios: The updated explanation details how energy consumption and distribution are modeled via the energy flows, using planned rates, meter data, or both, see Energy Distribution Scenarios.
  • Importing master data for Products using file upload: An example explains how to enter data for quantity conversions and quantity dimensions, see the section Example: Quantity Conversions and Dimensions in Products.
  • Data Inconsistencies: Guidelines on addressing these issues, see Business Transaction Data Consistency for details.
  • Delete imported business transaction data: More details on how to handle this process, see Deleting Business Transaction Data.

 

Catena-X Certification

In Q2, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management successfully was Catena-X certified by Cofinity-X, as the first carbon calculation software to receive this certification. Catena-X is the automotive industry’s open, collaborative data ecosystem, designed to facilitate secure and standardized data exchange across the entire value chain. With this certification, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management meets the rigorous calculation, interoperability, and data sovereignty standards required by Catena-X, enabling customers to seamlessly calculate and share trustworthy carbon footprint and sustainability data with partners, suppliers, and customers in the ecosystem. This not only supports regulatory and customer-driven transparency requirements but also paves the way for scalable decarbonization efforts in the automotive industry and beyond. By aligning with Catena-X, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management empowers organizations to participate confidently in cross-company sustainability initiatives within a rapidly evolving digital value network. With the integration to SAP Sustainability Data Exchange, carbon footprint data can be exchanged automatically and seamlessly.

 

Innovation Award Wins

We’re very proud to announce that two of our SAP Sustainability Footprint Management customers won the SAP Innovation Award 2025 in the Sustainability Hero category: Harting Technology Group and Matsumoto Precision!

Faced with the challenge of calculating carbon footprints for over 100,000 products across 14 factories, HARTING Technology Group needed a scalable, integrated solution. By becoming an early pilot customer of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, HARTING automated emissions tracking and achieved one-click carbon footprint calculations for 13,000 products – replacing a manual, time-consuming process. The solution, now live in three factories and expanding to all 14 by 2026, enables real-time, granular CO₂ data that supports HARTING’s “GreenLine” product label and helps meet stringent EU regulations like the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) and the Digital Product Passport. Thanks to this innovation, HARTING can now report that 85% of its packaging materials are recycled, and it has a clear path to achieving net-zero operations by 2030. This collaboration with SAP not only enhances transparency and compliance but also gives HARTING a competitive edge in customer bids – proving that sustainability and business success go hand in hand. Read the whole story here: HARTING - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

To address the growing demand for carbon transparency and operational efficiency, Matsumoto Precision implemented SAP S/4HANA alongside SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This combination gave the company real-time visibility into both product-level carbon emissions and profitability. With this data-driven approach, Matsumoto Precision was able to reduce its annual CO₂ emissions by 400 tons, increase productivity by 30 percent, and improve its operating profit margin by 3 percent. The factory now runs entirely on renewable energy, with on-site solar generation covering a significant portion of its needs. The implementation also empowered employees with real-time insights, leading to better decision-making and increased job satisfaction. Customers now receive verified carbon footprint data for each product, enhancing trust and supporting their own sustainability goals. In collaboration with Accenture, Matsumoto Precision even developed a generative AI tool that automates lifecycle flow diagrams, significantly reducing manual effort and streamlining emissions reporting. As CEO Toshitada Matsumoto put it, “With SAP S/4HANA and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we make smarter, greener decisions while tracking and visualizing CO₂ emissions for each product. And with this clarity, we can enhance our brand value.” Matsumoto Precision’s journey is a compelling example of how small and mid-sized manufacturers can lead the way in sustainable innovation by embedding carbon intelligence into every layer of their operations. Read the full story here: Matsumoto Precision Co., Ltd. - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

 

Customer Success Story: DMK

Germany’s largest dairy cooperative, DMK Deutsches Milchkontor GmbH, is leading the way in sustainable food production. Processing over 5.3 billion kilograms of milk annually, DMK is committed to reducing its environmental impact across the value chain. With ambitious climate goals – including a 42% reduction in Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2030 – DMK turned to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to bring transparency and precision to its carbon accounting.

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, DMK transformed how it calculates and manages product-level emissions. The solution enabled the company to move beyond industry averages and instead use granular, actual data to assess the carbon footprint of its milk-based products. This shift provided DMK with unprecedented transparency and accuracy, particularly in understanding and reporting Scope 3 emissions from its upstream value chain, such as milk production and transportation.

The digitalization of carbon footprint management not only helped DMK meet regulatory requirements but also strengthened its ability to respond to customer demands for credible, verifiable sustainability metrics. With SAP’s expert support and a tailored pilot program, DMK integrated emissions data directly into its product lifecycle, enabling more strategic decision-making and targeted decarbonization efforts.

This collaboration has positioned DMK as a leader in sustainable dairy production, demonstrating how digital tools can drive real progress toward climate goals while enhancing trust and transparency across the value chain. Read the full story here: DMK: Identifying the carbon footprint of milk-based products on the way to decarbonizing the value chain.

 

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

SAP’s commitment to sustainability is integrated into its core mission of improving economic, social, and environmental outcomes while respecting planetary and human rights boundaries. SAP is actively using its own sustainability software solutions to meet environmental and social goals, demonstrating an “SAP runs SAP” and “customer zero” approach. By implementing tools like SAP Green Ledger, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management within its operations, SAP treats sustainability management with the same rigor as financial reporting.

As a user, SAP faces challenges similar to its clients: collecting and managing large volumes of sustainability data, ensuring compliance with evolving regulations, and integrating data systems across the organization and supply chain. By implementing its sustainability solutions and continuously refining them through hands-on experience, SAP gains valuable insights that help improve its products for clients. Key lessons from their internal adoption include: ensuring consistent emissions data collection, grounding projects within governance frameworks, expanding focus beyond carbon to other environmental factors, and establishing a multi-layer data architecture for effective collection, processing, and reporting. The rollout of these systems is iterative, enabling refinement and adaptation—especially important as regulatory requirements change, such as the new EU Omnibus package. Overall, SAP aims to provide actionable sustainability insights, streamline ESG reporting, and drive both internal and customer progress toward measurable sustainability outcomes. To learn more, read the news article from Matthias Medert, SAP’s global head of Sustainability: SAP Runs Its Own Solutions for Sustainability Goals.

A central piece of the SAP runs SAP Sustainability IT architecture is SAP Sustainability Footprint Management:

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability - IT Architecture

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP has created a centralized and integrated platform to collect and calculate its corporate carbon emissions. The ambition is clear: to achieve full coverage of SAP’s carbon footprint through automated data collection and calculation. The software is much more than just a reporting tool, it acts as a central hub for emissions data, feeding into other SAP sustainability solutions such as the SAP Green Ledger, the SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and various internal systems. This enables comprehensive environmental impact analysis and supports regulatory compliance, while also informing strategic business decisions. Currently, SAP has already validated around 50% of its corporate carbon footprint within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This includes emissions from its own facilities like offices and data centers, as well as from shared infrastructure, cloud providers, and purchased goods and services.

The journey hasn’t been without challenges. At the outset, SAP faced difficulties in gathering and harmonizing data from multiple sources, each managed by different internal teams. Some of the data also required enrichment to be usable for sustainability purposes. However, through close collaboration between internal IT and business units, these hurdles were largely overcome, resulting in a more consistent and unified data flow.

Looking ahead, SAP aims to expand the system’s coverage to 100% of its corporate carbon footprint (excluding downstream emissions) before the planned business go-live in Q3. This milestone will involve five company codes and marks a significant step toward embedding sustainability deeper into SAP’s operations. All of this is being achieved through a continuous co-innovation process with SAP’s sustainability product engineering teams, demonstrating how SAP isn’t only building tools for others but also using them to lead by example. For all details, read the paper SAP runs SAP Sustainability: How to unlock the Power of Data on Sustainability Goals at Scale.

 

Learning Journey: PCF Calculation

The new Learning Journey Establishing the Product Carbon Footprint with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is the first one that focuses on Product Carbon Footprint (PCF) calculation. The one-hour self-learning is as all our Learning Journeys free of charge and targets consultants and business users with advanced product knowledge. It explains distributing Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions to products via various methods and covers how to use the energy flow model and planned consumption rates for Scope 1 and 2, as well as additional allocation schemes for Scope 3 emissions. By completing this journey, users will be able to calculate and allocate emissions from business activities, energy use, and resources to products, leveraging dedicated models and production documents. You’ll also earn a Record of Achievement and a digital badge after successful completion and passing all quizzes.

Learning Journey: Establishing the Product Carbon Footprint with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

This new PCF-centric Learning Journey complements our existing courses focusing on CCF calculation for beginners (Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Simple Configuration) and intermediates (Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Advanced Configurations).

 

Additional Information

To get more insights about the integration between SAP S/4HANA, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Data Exchange, and SAP Green Ledger, you should check out the blog post Where finance and carbon unite by @PreethaB. With a practical example, she explains how to track carbon throughout business processes and incorporate sustainability into operations. By showing the complete workflow, it’s demonstrated how integrated solutions provide valuable sustainability insights, support informed decision-making, help achieve sustainability goals, and improve operations.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower: Q2 2025 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the first half of 2025, global sustainability governance has entered a new phase of scrutiny and recalibration. The EU Omnibus amendments to the CSRD have postponed timelines and reduced the scope of immediate obligations for thousands of companies, temporarily easing the pressure of compliance. However, this regulatory pause has only sharpened the spotlight on data integrity, preparedness, and strategic ESG integration. 

At the same time, investors, regulators, and civil society are intensifying their expectations. Public disclosures are no longer judged on completeness alone—they must be audit-ready, aligned with recognized frameworks like ESRS and EU Taxonomy. Companies are expected to move beyond box-ticking compliance into continuous ESG performance management, proactively steering their sustainability journey. 

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) is designed precisely for this challenge. It enables organizations to: 

  • Record ESG factors with out-of-the-box integration to SAP systems and trusted third-party sources 
  • Analyze performance across financial, operational, and sustainability dimensions to support informed decisions 
  • Accelerate the transition through auditable, framework-aligned reporting—covering both regulatory and voluntary disclosures, powered by AI 

Building on our momentum from Q1, this quarter's updates focus on strengthening ESRS-aligned metric coverage, deeper analytical flexibility, improved auditability, and tighter alignment with financial structures. 

 

Expansion of SAP-provided metric coverage   

To support organizations on their ESRS compliance journey, SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) continues to expand its library of SAP-provided metrics aligned with the European Sustainability Reporting Standards. These include both qualitative and quantitative definitions based on EFRAG's implementation guidance. Current metric coverage is available in the SAP Help Portal and detailed in the SAP Community blog, offering transparency and reuse for accelerated implementation.  

 

Looking ahead, we plan to reach approximately 80% coverage of ESRS data points by the end of 2025, including metrics from ESRS 2, S2–S4, G1, and additional quantitative metrics from ESRS Topical Standards. This roadmap aims to enable our customers to progressively adopt SCT content for structured, auditable, and regulation-ready ESG disclosures while maintaining flexibility to extend for sector-specific or company-specific needs. 

 

Analyze ESG Data App Enhancements 

The Analyze ESG Data application now offers a significantly improved analytics experience with the introduction of the Analytics tab. Users can explore all standard custom quantitative metrics in greater depth by applying drill-down dimensions, choosing between chart or table formats, and configuring default views tailored to reporting needs. This new flexibility allows up to three charts to be displayed simultaneously, each with independent metric, period, and structure settings. 

In parallel, users can manage and switch between saved configurations of grouped metric tiles (“Overviews”), enabling different perspectives for different stakeholders or strategic priorities. Together, these enhancements empower users to personalize and streamline how ESG data is analyzed, viewed, and shared – supporting more informed decision-making and stronger alignment with sustainability goals. Find full details here: Using the Analyze ESG Data Application.

 

Custom Templates for “Generate ESG Reports with AI” App 

The Generate ESG Reports with AI app now offers greater flexibility and control through the introduction of custom templates. Users can create or edit templates to tailor the structure and content of ESG reports using available SAP-provided quantitative metrics.  

Within the Templates section, you can now select “Create” to build a new template or modify an existing one by adding sections and subsections, defining narrative text, and selecting from a predefined list of charts and tables. For each component, a content preview is available to ensure alignment with the selected reporting period. Once finalized, templates can be saved and reused, enabling consistent and structured ESG reporting across time periods.  

When generating a report, you can preview or download the result as a PDF—and for added customization, you can edit any section manually. SAP's built-in AI-assistance now supports dynamic revisions: simply select a passage and use the “Revise” option to receive suggestions to shorten or lengthen the text, helping refine your final ESG narrative with ease and speed. 

 

Fiscal Period Support 

The new Manage Fiscal Year Variants app brings flexible fiscal period support to SAP Sustainability Control Tower, allowing customers to define and activate custom fiscal year variants that align with their internal planning cycles. Whether using standard calendar months or granular date-based periods (like semi-monthly ranges), organizations can now tailor their ESG data analysis and reporting across key apps such as Analyze ESG Data, Manage GHG Data, and View Emission Dashboard. Built-in validation checks help ensure data compatibility, with options to consolidate or reimport data when switching to a new variant. This enables more accurate reporting, tighter alignment with financial periods, and greater control over how sustainability data is structured and interpreted across the organization. 

 

Change log updates 

In Q2, we've significantly improved transparency and traceability across SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT). Users can now track create, update, and delete changes to public overview configurations in the Analyze ESG Data app using the View Change Logs app. This functionality extends further, providing detailed logs for changes in business activity data, clearly showing the number of updated or imported records and distinguishing between actual and target data. 

 

New Languages Supported 

To better serve global enterprises, SAP SCT now supports Turkish and Italian languages. This update enables local teams to work in their native languages and enhances cross-regional collaboration on sustainability data collection and reporting. 

 

H2 2025 Roadmap Updates 

Looking ahead, we’re focused on simplifying and harmonizing ESG data consumption and reporting. A key milestone will be the delivery of a unified Read API for metric values – supporting both quantitative and qualitative data – to  make calculated ESG metrics easily accessible to external tools like disclosure management platforms. This API will also expose key metadata (including ESG standard references) and allow for both bulk and individual metric retrieval based on reporting scopes. We’re also working on improving flexibility in data modeling by enabling custom account groups, account-to-group mappings, and supporting activity data input through multiple channels. Additionally, we’ll continue expanding metric-level analysis, measure drilldowns, and export formats in the Analyze ESG data application. To enhance data quality and reporting alignment, we’re introducing tools for guiding data requirements based on double materiality, setting up reporting hierarchies and data sources, and improving transparency on data completeness. In parallel, we aim to deliver ESRS-aligned metric definitions that cover up to 70% of EFRAG's guidance, along with clear documentation and community updates to keep you informed as mentioned above. Stay tuned: SCT Roadmap Explorer. 

 

Additional Information 

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Control Tower, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

entry.title: SAP Green Token H1-25 Updates & Highlights: Raising the Bar on Sustainability Compliance
entry.content:
As sustainability regulations tighten, and global supply chains grow more complex,  SAP Green Token    continues to deliver pragmatic solutions for chain-of-custody, compliance, and operational clarity. Our H1 2025 release focuses on deepening support for the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR)

 

Making EUDR Work for Complex Supply Chains

SAP Green Token  delivers extended support for Article 9 of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR), covering both operator and trader personas—from inbound geolocation capture to DDS number generation and outbound data transfer

We built these capabilities for enterprise complexity. Whether managing dozens of sites, importing from outside the EU, or reducing supplier risk, Green Token simplifies compliance and provides a future-ready foundation.

✅Highlights from the H1 release:

  • Operator & Trader support: DDS generation, handling EU and non-EU suppliers, TRACES integration
  • Transactional-level reporting: Built on ERP data, avoids duplication, reduces risk
  • Open API integrations: Import GeoJSON and DDS data from portals, GR processes, or external systems

Figure 1: All end-to-end scenarios covered in SAP Green Token in H1

🔄Supporting Article 9 Workflows for the EU and Beyond

Global supply chains rarely follow a single linear flow. Most large enterprises manage multiple flows in parallel—across sites, regions, and regulatory jurisdictions. SAP Green Token is designed to handle exactly that.

We support inbound and outbound flow combinations under the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) including movements between EU and non-EU regions and across internal company sites. This enables companies to track, validate, and document material origin and DDS data across their full supply network—regardless of geography or supply chain complexity.

📥Built-In TRACES Integration
Green Token is directly connected to the EU TRACES system, enabling automated submission and tracking of DDS for both inbound and outbound shipments.

Based on your role (operator or trader), and the material flow direction, Green Token intelligently determines when to trigger TRACES submissions—minimizing errors, delays, and manual work. Simulation mode is also available for safe testing before go-live.

Why Transactional Reporting Matters

Most companies rely on annual reporting to track sustainability data—an approach still allowed under the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR). However, annual summaries can introduce risks, including outdated data, limited traceability, and delayed issue detection.

SAP Green Token offers an alternative: transactional-level reporting, seamlessly integrated with your ERP. This approach captures data per shipment, enabling real-time traceability, smarter DDS volume management, and proactive compliance.

✅Benefits:

  • More control: Filter by supplier, origin, or shipment quality
  • Risk isolation: One bad shipment won’t impact the entire batch
  • Smarter volume use: Avoid early DDS exhaustion
  • Lower long-term cost: Minimize corrections, fines, and rework

 

🎯Our Focus: Article 9, Done Exceptionally Well

SAP Green Token is purpose-built to support Article 9 of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR)—the most operationally complex and compliance-critical part of the regulation. Our solution is designed to handle the transactional- and geolocation-level data management, organization, and submission required of operators and traders at scale.

Green Token provides deep SAP integration, automated DDS management, TRACES submission, and audit-ready traceability, all optimized for ERP-driven supply chains.

🧩 We also leave white space for partners to extend the platform. For example, NTT Data independently built a supplier data management extension on top of Green Token for a customer—and we’re now exploring how to scale that model across the ecosystem.

This modular and integration-friendly approach enables customers and partners to build what's right for their workflows—without adding cost or complexity where it's not needed.

 

Enablement & Go-To-Market Assets: Everything You Need to Succeed

We released a full library of go-to-market and training assets to help teams implement Green Token.

Highlights include:

  • ISCC and EUDR demo systems
  • FAQs, L2 decks, pricing guides, onboarding content
  • Bi-monthly training sessions via Partner Portal
  • Integration & API guides

 

What’s Coming Next?

In H2 2025, we’re expanding into a completely new use case with support for the EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), marking Green Token’s first step into carbon-related compliance. We’ll also continue to strengthen our EUDR offering to support evolving regulatory and customer needs.

Curious how we’re tackling CBAM? Explore our first wave of materials here:

  • 📄The 6 things every CFO should do to prepare for CBAM — Thought leadership article by Gunther Rothermel on CFO.com
  • 🌐What is EU CBAM? — A quick-read content hub that answers key questions and explains SAP’s role
  • 🎥Watch now: CBAM Declarant Reporting with SAP Green Token – our new video walkthrough of how the solution supports CBAM compliance 

 

Stay in Touch

We’re committed to delivering solutions that solve real problems—and we want to hear from you.

  • Submit feedback via the SAP Influence Portal
  • Request a demo via your SAP representative
  • Follow me on SAP Community

entry.title: Navigating the New Milestone in Continuous Delivery of Regulatory Content
entry.content:
July 31st marks the latest Public Cloud Release for SAP S/4HANA for product compliance. Over the next weeks, we will look at new features and how they can used for your benefit. First is continuous delivery of regulatory content which has hit another milestone with the inclusion of safety data sheet management and authoring and product marketability compliance requirements.

How does this happen? First is the exchange format which has an entire compliance requirement included. Info included is ID, CR Pattern, URL, name of the compliance regulation, affected applications (like waste, radioactive), applicability area, issuing organization.

Next, well you have 2 options, the content comes with the newest release via our MIME repository, via the backend system using transaction se80. Zip files (which are moved manually from the MIME repository into the database tables) are created for each compliance requirement, under Product Compliance and then the area you want to update, for example Product Marketability. You can access and download the corresponding files to update your system. But these files are only updated when there is a new release.

Option 2 is our Regulatory Content Service which you can access in the Developer Hub and currently there are 4 APIs you can set up to deliver content to your system:

  • Compliance Requirements
  • Phrases
  • Graphics
  • Listed Substance Content

 

Once setup, a Job is scheduled, it will pull new or updated content into your system with no additional work. There is a Display Log to view what has been happening, for on-premise customers, this needs to be set up by an administrator. While this system does deliver content directly to your system, it doesn’t activate it, the user must do this in the Activate app which exist for Product Marketability, Safety Data Sheets and Dangerous Goods. One final note, to setup the Content Service, Public Cloud customers need to check out SAP Note 2999140 and Private Cloud and On-Premise customers SAP Note 3055767.

entry.title: Dangerous Goods Packing Instructions in Product Compliance
entry.content:
Every year more than 1.25 million dangerous goods shipments are transported by air. With air cargo growth predicted at 4.9% every year over the next 5 years the number of dangerous goods shipments will rise significantly. With so many dangerous goods being shipped by air, safety regulations must be followed precisely. IATA helps identify the risks and works with ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organization) to amend the regulations providing stakeholders with the most current guidelines on how to handle and ship dangerous goods safely. 

One of the data points we have been working on improving and expanding are the Packing Instructions for dangerous goods. We start out on the launchpad and go to the Manage Compliance Requirements Dangerous Goods.  

 From here we can see all the newly updated compliance requirement versions and we are going to choose IATA. IATA’s Dangerous Goods Regulation Manual (DGR) contains a list of approximately 3,000 articles and substances that are commonly shipped by air. We can see the new Packing Instructions and that we have over 2,300 already as part of the system for you to use.

But that is just an overview, in the View Regulatory Data app we can search for a specific UN number, in this case 1090 and see the applicable IATA enclosure-specific data sets along with the hazard label. In this app, you have packing instruction information for both single and combination packaging.

Now we can check the specific code and see the combination packaging info along with any additional requirements. For hazmat to be shipped by air, there are specific procedures to be met. First, the shipper must meet their criteria, such as declaring the shipment as dangerous goods, properly completing the Dangerous Goods Declaration, and adequately preparing the shipment for transport.

 

From an IATA publication we can see that packaging requirements of all types are a top priority when transporting dangerous goods. Safety is job number one when transporting dangerous goods, with SAP S/4HANA for product compliance we aim to make it easier and faster for you to get your products where they need to be.

entry.title: SAP EHS Environment Management - environmental responsibility and regulatory compliance
entry.content:
To assure environmental responsibility, regulatory compliance, and sustainable operations, SAP offers a comprehensive suite of solutions within SAP Environment, Health, and Safety – Environment Management, tailored to the needs of environmental managers, compliance specialists, and sustainability leaders.

At the heart of these solutions is the ability to centrally manage, monitor, and report on environmental aspects across the enterprise – from air emissions to regulatory obligations and waste streams – ensuring alignment with both legal requirements and corporate sustainability strategies.

Emission Management enables organizations to track, calculate, and report air pollutant and greenhouse gas emissions in line with local and international standards. By integrating operational data, it facilitates accurate emissions inventories, regulatory submissions, and transparent reporting, supporting both environmental impact reduction and corporate climate objectives.

Compliance Management provides a structured approach to managing all environmental obligations – whether arising from legislation, permits, or internal policies. Through a central repository for requirements and integrated task tracking, the solution reduces compliance risks, ensures timely execution, and enables clear documentation to demonstrate regulatory adherence.

Waste Management covers the complete lifecycle of waste handling – from identification and classification to transport, treatment, and final disposal – ensuring compliance with environmental regulations and corporate sustainability commitments. It streamlines waste tracking, documentation for hazardous and non-hazardous materials, and reporting for regulatory or internal purposes.

Below, you will find an introductory video for each of these topics, offering a concise overview of the solution scope and a glimpse into the user experience through mini demos. entry.title: Marketing and Sales Digital Transformation Story: SAP Social Sabbatical Program - Bhayli & SAP
entry.content:
⭐Bhayli & SAP: One Team, One Dream ⭐ Jai Seva — Victory in Service ⭐

As I look back on my final week in Jaipur, it feels like the culmination of not just a project, but of a journey of growth, collaboration, and shared purpose. What began four weeks ago with introductions, first impressions, and a steep learning curve has now come full circle with a clear strategy, a strong partnership, and lasting memories.

The SAP Social Sabbatical program brings together SAP employees from around the world to support innovative non-profits and social enterprises, helping them tackle real business challenges. Every organisation we’re working with are aligned with the UN Sustainable Development Goals, which makes this experience extremely meaningful, as it is fully aligned with some of my most treasured core values. This opportunity hits close to home — using the skills I’ve built over the years to support communities and businesses doing good in the world has always been a personal pursuit.

This last week marked an important milestone in our work with Bhayli — a women-led initiative that empowers artisans and supports the circular economy by transforming waste into beautiful, meaningful products. Bhayli empowers rural women in Rajasthan by training them to transform waste materials — like plastic bottles and beverage cans — into beautifully handwoven and handcrafted products. You can find more about Bhayli’s mission and vision in their website here and Instagram account here. Together with my SAP teammates Lucrecia Maphupha and Nidia Miguel in collaboration with Bhayli, we finalized a new Marketing and Sales phased business approach designed to capacitate Bhayli scale sustainably, strengthen its partnerships, and expand its impact.

Bhayli & SAP: One Team, One Dream

 

Design Thinking workshops

Building the Strategy

The fourth and last program week was all about bringing together the insights we had gathered over the previous three weeks. We refined the customer journeys, aligned on marketing opportunities, and worked through pricing strategies that would make sense both for Bhayli and its creative partners. It was an intense but rewarding process of distilling complex discussions into a clear, actionable roadmap.

One of the highlights of our collaboration with Bhayli was running a design thinking workshop with their team. The session brought together artisans, partners, and our sabbatical group to reimagine how Bhayli could expand its reach while staying true to its mission. Using hands-on exercises, we mapped customer needs, brainstormed new opportunities. What stood out most was the energy in the room: every idea, no matter how simple, sparked discussion, and every prototype carried a sense of pride and possibility. It was a powerful experience that not only generated practical insights for Bhayli’s growth but also built a deeper sense of connection and shared purpose among everyone involved.

There were moments of debate, brainstorming, and back-and-forth alignment — but that’s exactly what made the process so powerful. Each one of us brought different perspectives, shaped by our backgrounds and experiences, and those perspectives enriched the final outcome. It wasn’t just a project handed over — it was a true collaboration, built on trust and respect.

Bhayli's Business Growth Framework

Bhayli & SAP

 

The Final Presentation

Our program concluded with the final presentation, where we officially handed over the project deliverables. Standing together as a team, sharing our recommendations, and watching the Bhayli leadership nod with excitement and recognition was a moment of pride. It reminded me why programs like the SAP Social Sabbatical exist: to connect corporate skills with social impact, and to create bridges between business frameworks and grassroots innovation.

The presentation was more than a transfer of work — it was a celebration of the journey we had shared with Bhayli’s team, from long discussions over chai, to creative workshops shaping recycled materials, to aligning on business strategy that will help them grow their mission.

Final Presentation

Reflections on the Journey

As I reflect on these four weeks, what stands out most are not just the deliverables, but the people and experiences behind them. I think of the women artisans at Bhayli, whose creativity and resilience give life to products that carry both beauty and purpose. I think of the chaotic but vibrant streets of Jaipur — the honking symphony of traffic, the monsoon rains, the shared laughter over spicy meals. I think of my teammates, who became more than colleagues — they became friends, united by the shared challenge of making an impact.

This sabbatical has taught me that impact is rarely linear. It is messy, unpredictable, and sometimes overwhelming — but it is also deeply rewarding. By stepping out of our comfort zones, immersing ourselves in a new culture, and working alongside local partners, we not only helped build solutions but also learned to see the world through different lenses.

Taj Mahal visit

Gratitude

I am incredibly grateful to everyone who made this experience possible. To my fellow team members Lucrecia and Nidia— thank you for your dedication, your creativity, and your energy. To the Bhayli team, thank you for opening your doors, sharing your story, and allowing us to walk alongside you in this chapter of your journey. And to Pyxera Global, especially Shilpa Ahluwalia , Matrena Martin and Amisha Choudhary, thank you for organizing, guiding, and supporting us every step of the way. A big thanks to my extended SAP Team who shared this Journey with me: Evelyn Fromm, Oscar Fonque, Gisela Picaro, Daniel Fritsch, May Seet, Vera Volgina, Sebastian Lutz, Jackson Rogers, Carrie Barth and Vani Barg. Lastly I want to thank my manager Sam Forel for supporting me in this endeavor.

SAP Social Sabbatical Extended Team

Closing Thoughts - Key Takeaways

When I joined the SAP Social Sabbatical in Jaipur, I knew it would be a unique opportunity, but I didn’t realize just how much it would change me. My role was to work with Bhayli on creating a phased sales and marketing plan to capacitate their business scalability. On paper, it sounded like a familiar challenge. In reality, it pushed me far beyond my comfort zone and gave me lessons I’ll carry with me for years.

 The biggest change I experienced was building resilience, adaptability, and cultural awareness. Working in a completely new environment, with different ways of thinking and operating, forced me to let go of assumptions and really listen. It taught me to adapt quickly, stay resilient when things didn’t go as planned, and appreciate perspectives very different from my own.

 On a personal level, this opened my horizons. I discovered so much about Indian culture, the dedication of the artisans, and the sense of community around the work. I found myself becoming more empathetic, not only toward others but also in how I see the world — valuing patience, creativity, and the human stories behind every business.

Managing scope and expectations in an environment so different from my usual work strengthened my ability to navigate ambiguity and lead with clarity.
As a former SAP CRM consultant focusing in marketing and sales business, it felt refreshing being able to use my knowledge in this context. In additional, my experience as Customer Success Manager in building relationships and retaining SAP Customers, also contributed to reflect on strategies and best practices that can be adopted by  Bhayli.

I also gained a deeper understanding of how businesses in India — and particularly artisan-driven businesses — operate, which gave me fresh insights into ecosystems far outside the corporate world. On top of that, having the chance to engage directly with C-level leaders from local organizations helped me grow my confidence in stakeholder management and strategic conversations.

 Looking back, Jaipur wasn’t just about contributing my expertise — it was about growing as a person and a professional. I came back with a stronger sense of resilience, an openness to new perspectives, and practical leadership skills that I apply every day as a Customer Success Manager. More than anything, it reminded me that real impact comes from empathy, collaboration, and the willingness to learn as much as you give.

As our sabbatical in Jaipur comes to an end, I carry with me not just professional learnings, but also personal reflections. This experience was a reminder that true change happens when people come together with openness, humility, and a shared vision for a better future.

entry.title: Introducing Reporting Scope and Data Collection in SAP Sustainability Control Tower
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of the SAP Sustainability Control Tower as of September 1st, 2025.

Why SAP Developed Reporting Scope and Data Collection

SAP introduced the Reporting Scope and Data Collection feature in Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) to address the challenges organizations face when manually collecting sustainability data. Many customers struggled with decentralized, manual processes – often relying on emails and spreadsheets – which made it difficult to ensure data quality, traceability, and compliance with regulatory requirements. The new feature provides an integrated, workflow-based solution that guides users through the process, ensures relevant KPIs are collected, and supports collaboration between central and local teams. 

What Does the Feature Do?

The Reporting Scope and Data Collection feature enables organizations to:

  • Define which sustainability metrics are relevant for reporting.
  • Configure how data should be collected and who is responsible.
  • Guide users through a structured, form-based workflow for data entry, review, and approval.
  • Track and manage data collection runs for different reporting periods.
  • Ensure data is captured, approved, and stored in a traceable manner. 

Step-by-Step Guide: SAP SCT Applications

  1. Manage Reporting Scope
  • Define the scope of sustainability reporting by selecting relevant metrics and organizational boundaries.
  • Set validity dates and add comments for each metric (e.g., materiality, monitoring purposes).
  • Capture the results of double materiality assessments and specify which KPIs require data collection.
  • In this simplified example the organizational boundary is set to Business Region EMEA and the Scope Items are the ESRS items Total energy consumption related to own operations - E1-5 - (37)(AR 35) and Total water consumption - E3-4 - (28a).

  1. Configure Data Collection
  • Assign data processors and approvers for each scoped metric and organizational entity.
  • Choose the data collection method (e.g., workflow-based).
  • Ensure responsibilities are clear for each data point to streamline collaboration

  1. Configure Data Entry
  • Customize the data entry form for each metric, including the data collection cycle (e.g., monthly, quarterly or yearly) and required breakdowns by a master data dimension.
  • Add instructions and enable relevant dimensions to guide processors during data entry

  1. Manage Data Collection Instances
  • Set up data collection runs for specific reporting years and periods.
  • Define start, submission, and approval dates to control the workflow timeline.
  • Generate forms for each reporting period and metric, ensuring timely data collection. 

  1. Manage Data Collection Forms
  • Preview and send out data collection forms to assigned processors.
  • Processors enter data and submit for approval; approvers review, approve, or reject submissions.
  • Approved data is published and stored, with full traceability in SCT. 

 

This new workflow-based approach in SAP SCT streamlines sustainability data collection, improves data quality, and supports compliance with evolving regulatory standards.

Feature status and outlook: Currently, the feature supports quantitative metrics and measures for sustainability reporting. In future iterations, SAP plans to include qualitative metrics and basic custom metrics, as well as additional data entry methods, plausibility checks, multi-step approvals and email notifications based on customer feedback.

For further support, please also visit Data Collection Workflow for Quantitative Metrics | SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: SAP Green Token for EUDR: Simplifying Compliance at Scale
entry.content:
The EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) is reshaping how companies source and trade key commodities in the EU. From December 2025, large companies trading commodities such as cocoa, palm oil, soy, rubber, cattle, coffee, and timber must prove their products are deforestation-free. SMEs will follow by June 2026.

The stakes are high. Non-compliance can mean fines of up to 4% of annual EU turnover, blocked shipments, exclusion from public tenders, and long-term reputational damage. Yet most companies are not ready for the deep traceability that EUDR requires, right down to the plot of land where commodities originate.

This is where SAP Green Tokencomes in.

Who is affected by EUDR?

The regulation applies broadly across the supply chain:

  • First-time Operators: Companies that first place commodities on the EU market or export them from the EU. First-time operators must perform full due diligence: collecting data (Article 9), conducting risk assessments (Article 10), mitigating risks (Article 11), and DDS creation & management (Article 4).
  • Downstream Operators & Traders: Companies that make relevant products available in the EU market after they have been placed there. Their obligations focus on record-keeping and referencing upstream due diligence statements (DDS) (Article 4 + 5).
  • Non-EU Suppliers: Not directly liable under EUDR, but they must provide EU customers with verified sustainability data according to Article 9 (geolocation, deforestation-free declarations) or risk losing access to EU supply chains.

This wide scope means global coordination across suppliers, producers, importers, and traders is essential.

 Figure 1. Why EUDR matters

 

Why DDS Management is the Cornerstone

At the heart of EUDR compliance lies Due Diligence Statement (DDS) management. Every operator and trader, regardless of role, must handle DDS in some form:

  • Article 4 (Operators): Operators must create and submit DDS in TRACES, ensuring products are deforestation-free and legally produced.
  • Article 5 (Traders): Traders must manage and reference upstream DDS, keeping records to prove that due diligence was exercised earlier in the chain.
  • Article 9 (Information Requirements): Defines the detailed data each DDS must contain: from geolocation of plots of land to production details, supplier information, and legality declarations.

DDS must be submitted in the EU’s TRACES system and retained for at least five years. Without robust DDS management, companies cannot prove compliance, making it the true cornerstone of any EUDR strategy.
 

Why annual reporting is too risky

Some companies consider preparing one DDS per year to cover all volumes. On paper, this looks simpler. In reality, it creates risk:

  • One bad shipment could invalidate the entire batch.
  • Annual aggregation makes it harder to trace products back to individual plots of land.
  • Errors may only surface months later, when it’s too late to correct them without penalties.
  • Fixed annual DDS volumes may be “used up” too early, forcing resubmissions mid-year.
  • And critically: geolocation data must be collected for each batch regardless. Even if reported annually, the effort is the same — while exposing companies to much higher compliance risk.

In contrast, transactional reporting is safer and more agile:

  • Each shipment is tracked individually, limiting exposure if an issue arises.
  • Errors are detected early, reducing compliance risk and correction costs.
  • Companies maintain continuous oversight instead of year-end surprises.

This is why SAP Green Token is purpose-built for transaction-level traceability and not annual summaries.

 Figure 2. Green Token - Inbounds overview for EUDR

 

How SAP Green Token simplifies EUDR compliance

Green Token was designed to help companies comply with material accounting standards, such as EUDR, at scale. Here’s how:

  • Transactional-level reporting
    Captures data at the delivery level, linking each shipment to origin, sustainability data, and geolocation.
  • Built-in TRACES integration
    Automatically generates DDS, submits them into TRACES, and retrieves reference numbers back into Green Token.
  • Chain-of-custody management
    Maintains segregated accounting for multi-tier, multi-site supply chains, ensuring full auditability.  Because EUDR requires strict segregation of compliant and non-compliant flows, Green Token makes this process automated and auditable.
  • Open API for geo-spatial- and risk tools
    Connects with external geospatial and risk assessment platforms via GeoJSON, enabling Article 10 risk analysis.
  • Audit-ready by design
    Stores DDS and supporting data for 5+ years, with transparent reporting and real-time visibility for inspections.
  • Support for EU and non-EU companies
    Green Token supports operators, traders, authorized representatives, and even non-EU suppliers, enabling them to provide the data EU customers need.

The result: compliance becomes a continuous, automated process, not a manual, reactive scramble.

How it works in practice

Implementing Green Token for EUDR follows five simple steps:

  1. Capture delivery data from ERP or CSV sources.
  2. Map EUDR attributes (geolocation, supplier IDs, DDS reference numbers).
  3. Generate DDS automatically in the correct TRACES format.
  4. Integrate with TRACES to submit DDS and pull official DDS reference numbers back into Green Token.
  5. Store and report data for auditing, with full transaction-level granularity.

This streamlined approach makes it possible for even complex, global supply chains to stay compliant without creating parallel systems or manual overhead.

 Figure 3. Green Token - Set Up Overview

 

Why SAP Green Token is different 

While other solutions focus narrowly on risk assessment or certificates, SAP Green Token delivers enterprise-scale compliance:

  • Transactional-level EUDR attributes & reporting: One of the few solutions that captures DDS data (geolocation, supplier IDs, DDS references) at the shipment/delivery level, instead of relying on aggregated annual reports.
  • ERP-native integration: Reuse supplier, material, and delivery data directly from SAP ERP, no duplicate entries.
  • Scalable for complexity: Handle multi-site, multi-commodity flows and adapt to evolving regulations like EUDR and CBAM.
  • Future-proof: Already supporting Authorized Representatives (Article 6) and ready to adapt to Omnibus updates.
  • Trusted partner ecosystem: Connect with external geospatial and audit partners through open APIs.

Only SAP Green Token combines transactional granularity, DDS Management, TRACES integration, and ERP-native scalability in one platform.

EUDR is not just another compliance exercise. It’s a structural shift in how companies prove sustainability across global supply chains. For operators, traders, and suppliers alike, the key to compliance lies in accurate, auditable, and automated DDS management.

That’s why SAP Green Token is the starting point to make it happen.
